lead_paragraph: “PERHAPS IF IT is your first try, you don't deserve it,” said a ruefully philosophic Maj. Christopher Davey, one of two Britons who failed — by 140 miles to make the first balloon crossing of the Atlantic. He and Donald Cameron returned to England yesterday, fighting back tears and finally admitting that they were “quite disgust. ed” and “absolutely miserable” over having to ditch their yellow, helium and hot air balloon in the Atlantic Sunday. French fishermen picked them up and took them to the port of Concarneau in Brittany. Yesterday they took a private plane to Bracknell, England. Their $300,000 adventure, which came closer to success than any of the 18 known previous attempts, began in Newfoundland last Wednesday.

abstract: Japanese Natl Police Agency repts number of crimes in Japan increased 6.3% during first 6 mos of '78, totaling 631,929; breakdown of figures (S)
snippet: Japanese Natl Police Agency repts number of crimes in Japan increased 6.3% during first 6 mos of '78, totaling 631,929; breakdown of figures (S)
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, July 31 (AP) — The number of crimes in Japan increased 6.3 percent during the first six months of 1978, totaling 631,929, the National Police Agency reported. The number of assaults decreased 4.2 percent, to 4,717 cases, but the number of people injured in robberies rose 4.1 percent and attacks on women increased 21.7 percent.

abstract: Washington Journal article on fund-raising event for Peter F Flaherty, Dem candidate for Penna Gov, in Washington, DC (M)
snippet: Washington Journal article on fund-raising event for Peter F Flaherty, Dem candidate for Penna Gov, in Washington, DC (M)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON IN THE PARLANCE of his profession, Peter J. Flaherty was “working the room,” a well‐appointed, dimly lighted salon at a local hotel. Smiling broadly for more than two hours, the former Mayor of Pittsburgh and former Deputy Attorney General of the United States moved with no apparent haste from one group of people to another, stepping casually into the flow of their small talk to offer his big hand, call them all by their first names,’ drape an arm around waiting male shoulders, drop kisses on expectant female cheeks, laugh heartily at this or that and, then, his face properly serious, assess optimistically his gubernatorial campaign in Pennsylvania before shaking hands all around again and heading to the next little clutch.

abstract: Rain‐bearing clouds are drifting slowly across the mid and north•Atlantic States and pass out to sea later today and tonight. A new cold front is forming clouds across southern Canada.

abstract: Robert Shaw leads Westminster Choir in performance of Brahms's ‘A German Requiem’ at Avery Fisher Hall; Donal Henahan rev (M)
snippet: Robert Shaw leads Westminster Choir in performance of Brahms's ‘A German Requiem’ at Avery Fisher Hall; Donal Henahan rev (M)
lead_paragraph: THE meditations on death and transfiguration that Brahms culled from the. Bible as a text for his “A German Requiem” are not unrelievedly grim or funereal. At one point we are assured, for instance, that when the redeemed return to Zion “joy everlasting upon their heads shall be.- But somber senti- ments do predominate, as they probably should in a requiem, and that presents grave problems, so to speak, for the interpreter. Treated imaginatively, the solemn speculations of Brahms can give the susceptible listener the illusion of glimpsing eternity. Handled in a more dogged, plodding manner, the seven‐movement work can suggest the reality of eternity rather than the illusion.

snippet: Issue and Debate article on controversy over use of private funds to sponsor Games (M)
lead_paragraph: The rules of the International Olympic Committee require that arrangements to stage the Olympic Games be made only with officials of the site. When Los Angeles was chosen for the 1989 Summer Games, controversy, arose about the financial obligations involved, and proposals were made to have private‐sector sponsors — among them a television network — underwrite the cost. But I.O.C. regulations specifically prohibit such a procedure, and the whole question of holding the games in Los Angeles was in doubt.

lead_paragraph: President Carter has finally issued his “principles” for a national health insurance program.mere downpayment, and a belated one, on his campaign promise to act swiftly in this area. The principles are broad enough, and vague enough, to satisfy many citizens. Yet even before they were issued, Senator Kennedy and other advocates of broad health coverage for all denounced the President for a failure of leadership. The issue between them is how much how soon.

abstract: Jury selection begins in trial of Peter Leonard, who is charged with setting fire in Port Chester (NY) discotheque that killed 24 persons in '74; Leonard had pleaded guilty to charge but plea was later dismissed by appeals ct on grounds that admission was forced by police; he later pleaded guilty to setting fire to bowling alley to cover up burglary there; flames spread to discotheque (S)
snippet: Jury selection begins in trial of Peter Leonard, who is charged with setting fire in Port Chester (NY) discotheque that killed 24 persons in '74; Leonard had pleaded guilty to charge but plea was later dismissed by appeals ct on grounds that admis...
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS, July 31 (AP) — Jury selection began today in the trial of Peter Leonard of Greenwich, Conn., who is charged with setting a fire in a Port Chester discotheque that killed 24 persons in 1974. Mr. Leonard had pleaded guilty to the charge, but the plea was later dismissed by an appeals court on the ground that the admission had been forced by the police.Two and a half years ago, Mr. Leonard pleaded guilty to setting fire to bowling alley to cover up a burglary there. The flames spread to the discotheque.

lead_paragraph: IN “Chesapeake,” his 21st book, James A. Michener does for Maryland's Eastern Shore what he did for Colorado in “Centennial.” By telling the story of dozens of fictional characters who live in a partly imaginary locale, he tries to capture the real history of the area — in the case of the Chesapeake Bay, from the time in the 16th century when Indians and crabs were its chief inhabitants.

abstract: Ed says Gov Carey's vow to oppose construction of nuclear power plants in NY until Fed Govt devises program for dealing with nuclear wastes will contribute little to solution of waste-disposal problem; says it was adopted in casual manner, has no legal force and appears to be primarily an exercise in election-yr posturing
snippet: Ed says Gov Carey's vow to oppose construction of nuclear power plants in NY until Fed Govt devises program for dealing with nuclear wastes will contribute little to solution of waste-disposal problem; says it was adopted in casual manner, has no ...
lead_paragraph: Governor Carey's dramatic vow to block construction of nuclear power plants in New York State until the Federal Government comes up with an “adequate” waste disposal‐program seems to be primarily an exercise in election‐year posturing. The problem of nuclear wastes — radioactive material that must be kept isolated for hundreds of thousands of years — is real enough and has received insufficient attention. But the Governor's gesture will contribute little to the search far a solution.

abstract: 3 scuba divers die while diving in cave, Live Oak, Fla, that has history of fatal accidents; sheriffs office repr Bill Maxwell says divers apparently became lost in underwater cave and air supply gave out (S)
snippet: 3 scuba divers die while diving in cave, Live Oak, Fla, that has history of fatal accidents; sheriffs office repr Bill Maxwell says divers apparently became lost in underwater cave and air supply gave out (S)
lead_paragraph: LIVE OAK, Fla., July 31 (AP) —Three scuba divers on an outing from Albany, Ga., died while diving in a cave near here where dozens of lives have been lost in recent years, sheriff's officials said today. A spokesman for the sheriff's office, Bill Maxwell, said the three were diving in large pool called Peacock's Slough, which is posted against diving and has a history of fatal accidents. He said they apparently became lost in a large underwater cave and their air supply ran out.

abstract: FULL BLOOM Roseland, which has introduced several innovations and special events for patrons since the large dance palace attained new prominence with the movie filmed there, is now offering dancers its most inclusive package yet. Each Wednesday, starting tonight at 5:30 P.M., an entrance fee of $10 covers all you can eat and drink until closing. In addition to the regular ballroom spinning to two bands, there will be a 9:15 dance class, then a dance show and, finally, disco dancing starting at midnight (as it also does on Fridays and Saturdays).

abstract: Econ Min repts foreign tourists spent some $3.4 billion in in '77, up 10% from '76 (S)
snippet: Econ Min repts foreign tourists spent some $3.4 billion in in '77, up 10% from '76 (S)
lead_paragraph: BERN, Aug. 1 (Reuters) — The steady fall of most currencies against the Swiss franc did not discourage foreign tourists from spending their cash in Switzerland last year, statistics showed today. The Economics Ministry reported that foreign tourists spent more than $3.4 billion in this country in 1977, according to current exchange rates. That was a 10 percent increase over the previous year. Tourism and banking traditionally give Switzerland a balance-of-payments surplus despite its usual trade deficit — $960 million last year — caused by importing essential raw materials.

abstract: Like many recent American Presidents, New York's Mayor Koch has learned that it is as hard to control his own administration as it is to influence an independently elected legislature. To bring some order into the far‐flung city establishment and to root out corrupt practices, the Mayor has ordered each department to set up an inspector general's office. For 11 of the 25 departments, this was nothing new. They have had them and they have not worked too well. But the Mayor believes that by placing his Commissioner of Investigation in overall charge, he can control the inspectors while they monitor the rank-and-file city workers.
lead_paragraph: Like many recent American Presidents, New York's Mayor Koch has learned that it is as hard to control his own administration as it is to influence an independently elected legislature. abstract: Ed calls for passage of Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of '78, which outlines procedures for wiretapping and seeks to curb abuses without weakening nation's defenses against espionage and terrorism; notes many diverse groups support legis (M)
snippet: Ed calls for passage of Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of '78, which outlines procedures for wiretapping and seeks to curb abuses without weakening nation's defenses against espionage and terrorism; notes many diverse groups support legis (...
lead_paragraph: Wiretapping by Government for purposes of “foreign intelligence” and “national security” ought to be under the control of law. The House of Representatives now faces the challenge — and opportunity of enactment. The Senate's version of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act 011978 passed by a vote of 95 to 1, but harder fight against the measure is promised by the House Republican Policy Committee. We hope the House will recognize the national interest in ending the abuses of wiretapping that have occurred under eight Presidents—and pass this important bill.

lead_paragraph: OUTSIDE, the temperature is over 90 degrees and the city smells of car exhaust and hot knishes. Inside, deep underground below 20th Street and Fifth Avenue, the air is cool and smells of burnt elm- powder, hot oil and that nose‐tingling blend of lead, brass and gunsmoke that would tell you what's going on here even if you couldn't hear the reports from a dozen pistols being fired just the other side of a glass partition. The place the West Side Pistol and Rifle Range. It's Saturday morning, the weekly meeting of the Chelsea Gun Club, and the members are sitting around chatting and talking about guns before they take their turns on the range.

abstract: Ed note on Denver Fed appeals ct ruling that laws requiring drugs to be proved 'safe' and 'effective' before they are sold in interstate commerce have no meaning for terminally ill cancer patients; citing laetrile controversy, ed suggests status quo, in which individual gives up some freedom of choice, should not be lightly abandoned
snippet: Ed note on Denver Fed appeals ct ruling that laws requiring drugs to be proved 'safe' and 'effective' before they are sold in interstate commerce have no meaning for terminally ill cancer patients; citing laetrile controversy, ed suggests status q...
lead_paragraph: Should a terminally ill cancer patient be allowed to take the drug of his choice even though medical authorities consider it worthless and perhaps even dangerous? A Federal appeals court in Denver believes so. In a case involving the controversial laetrile, it has ruled that laws requiring drugs to be proved “safe” and “effective” before they are sold in interstate commerce have no meaning for terminally ill cancer patients. If upheld on appeal, the decision could undermine the Food and Drug Administration's ability to protect consumers from fraud and possible hazard.

abstract: WE are used to being told how to cook, how to improve our emotional state, and how to fix a leaky faucet, but not how to see. lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1 (UPI) — A 15year‐old South American boy was arrested at Los Angeles International Airport yesterday with two and a half pounds of cocaine in his suitcase, the authorities said. United States customs inspectors said that the cocaine had a street value of $700,000. The unidentified teen‐ager arrived at the airport from Lima, Peru, on his way to Vancouver, British Columbia. He was booked on suspicion of transporting narcotics. And turned over to the county probation department.

abstract: NYS Health Dept is scheduled to recommend on Aug 2 whether Gov Carey should declare health emergency in Love Canal area of Niagara Falls, where chem wastes buried by Hooker Chem Co 25 yrs ago are leaking from their rotting containers and leaching their way into backyards and basements of 100 homes and public school built near dump site; 82 indus chems, 11 of them suspected carcinogens, have surfaced, causing chem burns to dogs and children, burning soles of shoes and destroying trees and vegetation; seepage into basements has caused levels of certain chems to rise 250-5,000 times higher than safety limit in some homes; residents have miscarriage rate of 29.4%, and 4 out of 24 children born to families in 1 part of canal have birth defects and are mentally retarded; residents say many in neighborhood have died of rectal, breast and blood cancers; Eckhardt C Beck of EPA says site is 1 of 38 known indus waste landfills in Niagara County, and probably most serious health hazard of thousands in nation; Hooker has offered to share cleanup costs; Niagara Falls appears to have been uncooperative with neighborhood requests for help and with state and Fed agencies; Repr John LaFalce is investigating whether Army dumped chem warfare materials into canal, as retired city bulldozer operator has charged; Karen Schroeder, resident who first raised public concern, comments; illus; map (M)

abstract: DESPITE an ever‐increasing availability of creatures from the sea, Americans are not fish lovers. Last year, we consumed a mere 13 pounds of fish and seafood per person — compared with 52 pounds of chicken and 165 of red meat. And it is no wonder. The aquatic woria of fins, scales and shells can indeed be mysterious. And aside from familiarity with fish and chips dinners and an occasional lobster tail, many Americans would have difficulty describing the differences between a mullet and a mussel, a whiting and a weakfish. There are, of course, as many varieties of food of the deep as there are ways to prepare them. And to be at home with the soft brininess of a freshly opened oyster, to drink in the perfume of wine‐steamed mussels, to savor the essense of salmon in the form of faintly sweet, dill‐pungent gravlax, is to want to experiment with an even greater range of possibilities. Summer is an ideal time to experiment, to “go fishing,” since many types of fish and seafood are at their peak now, and can be served raw, lightly pickled or marinated, or cooked and then chilled. While raw fish dishes are common to the Japanese, some Western Indian tribes and the Eskimos, Americans, who have eaten steak tartare and fresh raw oysters for centuries, are just learning to like the delicate aroma and flavor of the Japanese sushi and sashimi. Caution should, of course, be exercised here, limiting raw fish to salt water, not fresh water, varieties. More familiar are the pickled or marinated fish and seafood, in the form or the classic Peruvian seviche, Spanish escabeche or Norwegian herring. Many kinds of fish and seafood can be “cured” by brief marination in a citric acid base combined with onions, red pepper, oil and spices for a sharp and piquant summer dish. Here, leaner fish are best, with many local varieties reaching peak production this month. Whiting, red snapper, floun- der, halibut and mackerel are all “in season,” and excellent for marinating. Sea scallops, used for the traditional seviche, also reach peak production in August. Finally there are the many dishes that, while delicious served hot during cool months, take on a totally different flavor in the summer. Among them are poached red snapper, steamed mussels and cooked squid.
lead_paragraph: DESPITE an ever‐increasing availability of creatures from the sea, Americans are not fish lovers. Last year, we consumed a mere 13 pounds of fish and seafood per person — compared with 52 pounds of chicken and 165 of red meat. And it is no wonder. The aquatic woria of fins, scales and shells can indeed be mysterious. And aside from familiarity with fish and chips dinners and an occasional lobster tail, many Americans would have difficulty describing the differences between a mullet and a mussel, a whiting and a weakfish. There are, of course, as many varieties of food of the deep as there are ways to prepare them. And to be at home with the soft brininess of a freshly opened oyster, to drink in the perfume of wine‐steamed mussels, to savor the essense of salmon in the form of faintly sweet, dill‐pungent gravlax, is to want to experiment with an even greater range of possibilities. Summer is an ideal time to experiment, to “go fishing,” since many types of fish and seafood are at their peak now, and can be served raw, lightly pickled or marinated, or cooked and then chilled. While raw fish dishes are common to the Japanese, some Western Indian tribes and the Eskimos, Americans, who have eaten steak tartare and fresh raw oysters for centuries, are just learning to like the delicate aroma and flavor of the Japanese sushi and sashimi. Caution should, of course, be exercised here, limiting raw fish to salt water, not fresh water, varieties. More familiar are the pickled or marinated fish and seafood, in the form or the classic Peruvian seviche, Spanish escabeche or Norwegian herring. Many kinds of fish and seafood can be “cured” by brief marination in a citric acid base combined with onions, red pepper, oil and spices for a sharp and piquant summer dish. Here, leaner fish are best, with many local varieties reaching peak production this month. Whiting, red snapper, floun- der, halibut and mackerel are all “in season,” and excellent for marinating. Sea scallops, used for the traditional seviche, also reach peak production in August. Finally there are the many dishes that, while delicious served hot during cool months, take on a totally different flavor in the summer. Among them are poached red snapper, steamed mussels and cooked squid.

abstract: Family tensions. Woody Allen makes like Ingmar Bergman, brilliantly.
snippet: Family tensions. Woody Allen makes like Ingmar Bergman, brilliantly.
lead_paragraph: TO describe "Interiors" as Woody Allen's first serious drama is to stress the irrelevant. Mostly, though, it's to overlook the earnestness of all his comedies, from "Take the Money and Run" to "Annie Hall," as well as the upside-down gravity of his familiar comic locutions that shrink Large Subjects to takeout size. "There is no question that there is an unseen world," he once wrote in a trenchant essay titled "Examining Psychic Phenomena." "The problem is, how far is it from midtown and how late is it open?"All of Mr. Allen's films have been serious to a certain degree, and they have been getting seriouser and seriouser as he has developed into one of America's most original, most personal, most audacious writer-directors. "Annie Hall" is a comedy of rare spirit, and it's as serious as any American film made in the last decade.Rather than describe "Interiors" as his first serious drama, I think it's more precise to say that it's the first Woody Allen film that doesn't care to be funny, That's something else entirely."Interiors," which opens today at the Baronet, is a culture shock. Not to be prepared for it is to embark on a Miami Beach vacation having just taken a total immersion course in 17th-century English literature."Interiors" looks beautiful. It has been photographed by Gordon Willis in cool colors that suggest civilization's precarious control of natural forces. Woody himself is nowhere to be seen. It actually looks very much like an Ingmar Bergman film, and even sounds like one — the specific flatness of the Allen dialogue, its fondness for the jargon of the analysand, being the spoken equivalent to the not always inspired but perfectly functional English subtitles for Mr. Bergman's Swedish dialogue.There is even something foreign about the members of the middle-class New York family who are the center of the drama. They seem as socially disconnected from the world around them as they are emotionally and psychically disconnected from themselves and from one another. It's not simply that the movie concentrates so intensely on its characters, but that there are virtually no other people in sight. We do see people passing in the street, in corridors, in cars on highways, and we see, one time each, a small child and a Protestant minister, but it still seems as if the family inhabited its own empty, very spooky universe."Interiors" is not inaptly titled. From the opening sequence, a series of shots looking out at the sea from the sparely furnished rooms of a large, handsome Long Island beach house, it's apparent that we are to be given a film about emotional drain, unfulfilled longings and vaguely defined fears — things that are never easy to describe and always difficult to dramatize. Mr. Allen's characters are in the furious grip of making do. They are seized — and sometimes overcome — by the need to accommodate the common-place.They are Renata (Diane Keaton), the eldest daughter who is identified as a successful poet, and her husband Frederick (Richard Jordan), who is an unsuccessful novelist; Joey (Marybeth Hurt), the youngest daughter, a failed artist and actress who'd like to write and who lives on scratchy terms with a film maker named Mike (Sam Waterston); Flyn (Kristin Griffith), the middle daughter, a successful actress who makes dopey television films; Eve (Geraldine Page), the mother of the girls, an interior decorator and a woman who remains on the edge of despair because her longtime marriage to Arthur (E.G. Marshall), a very rich lawyer, is coming apart, and Pearl (Maureen Stapleton), the buxom, warmhearted widow Arthur now wants to marry.My problem with "Interiors" is that although I admire the performances and isolated moments, as well as the techniques and the sheer, headlong courage of this great, comic, film-making philosopher, I haven't any real idea what the film is up to. It's almost as if Mr. Allen had set out to make someone else's movie, say a film in the manner of Mr. Bergman, without having any grasp of the material, or first-hand, gut feelings about the characters. They seem like other people's characters, known only through other people's art.Could it possibly be that "Interiors" is really a Brooklyn Jewish boy's fantasy about middle-class American Protestantism? But I'm not even sure whether the family in the movie is Protestant, Catholic or Jewish. They could be anything because they are placed in no identifiable social context, something that Mr. Bergman never has had to worry about (until "The Serpent's Egg") because he has always dealt with the terrors of a thoroughly homogenized society.Miss Page, looking a bit like a youthful Louise Nevelson with mink-lashed eyes, is marvelous — erratically kind, impossibly demanding, pathetic in her loneliness and desperate in her anger. Miss Stapleton beautifully projects the tone and feelings of a sweet, robust, coarse woman who is never, never ridiculous. Mr. Marshall is also fine as the husband whose desperation matches his wife's, though it is disciplined by purpose. The other roles are more difficult to judge because the material is so nebulous.Miss Hurt is very appealing as the youngest daughter who hates her mother and, thus, goes out of her way to convince herself she doesn't. Her feelings of creative impotence are also understandable, but I don't know what we are meant to feel for her when she writes in her diary, "Today I couldn't help experiencing a few nostalgic memories." She suddenly sounds like one of those humorless college types — a young woman who aspires to talk beyond her degree — that appear so frequently in Mr. Allen's written literature.Mr. Waterston's role doesn't make any outrageous demands on him, but Mr. Jordan's unsuccessful novelist — as written — is very much the bearded, hard-drinking, tough-talking novelist that's been a Hollywood cliché since movies began to talk. He just writes for higher-toned periodicals (The New York Review of Books).The most difficult role is Miss Keaton's. It's probably impossible to write or act convincingly a character who's supposed to be a successful poet. Just what constitutes success for a poet? Being published in The New Yorker? Winning famous awards (never mentioned in the film)? Not combing your hair and still looking great? Being miserable? From the dialogue and insights Mr. Allen gives her, Renata sounds as if she might really be quite a bad poet, at least when she goes on about being "hyper-aware of her body."Though the movie looks beautiful, the elegant style occasionally works against it, showing it up. This happens in a striking close-up of Miss Keaton, sitting alone on a photogenically windswept ocean beach as she is supposed to be thinking sensitive poet-type thoughts. Yet the image is empty. It's not the actress. It's not the director, whose close-ups of Miss Keaton in "Annie Hall" burst with love, pride and affection. The movie that contains the image fails to invest it with any associations whatsoever.

abstract: Morton I Sosland article on ways in which US grain reserve can contribute to domestic and world food security (M)
snippet: Morton I Sosland article on ways in which US grain reserve can contribute to domestic and world food security (M)
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo.—The United States has built up a sizable reserve of grain: nearly 600 million bushels at the last count. Wheat holdings alone are at 370 million bushels, about two‐thirds of a year's domestic food use. Since addi- tions to the stock are still under way, is possible that the reserve eventually may approach the huge billion‐bushel stocks held in the early 1960's.

abstract: pianist Peter Serkin, violinist Alexander Schneider and cellist Yo-Yo Ma perform; Ma por; Harold C Schonberg rev (M)
snippet: pianist Peter Serkin, violinist Alexander Schneider and cellist Yo-Yo Ma perform; Ma por; Harold C Schonberg rev (M)
lead_paragraph: THE success of the Mostly Mozart concerts in Avery Fisher Hall is little short of a phenomenon. Night after night the hall is sold out, with an overflow on the stage, and so it was on Tuesday night for the program of chamber music. An eager audience, anticipatory and enthusiastic, was on hand to greet the three musicians of the evening‐Peter Serkin, pianist, Alexander Schneider, violinist, and Yo‐Yo Ma, cellist. They played Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert.

abstract: Q. Before moving into our turn-ofthe‐century house a year ago we had refinished a large chest of drawers that has been in my family for many years . Of.course, none of the drawers or the chest itself were finished on the inside. Now all the drawers, which worked fine before, seem to be hard to open and close. A lubricant helped a little, but not enough. Do you think the refinishing affected the drawers in some way and do you have any suggestions about what to do? — H.P.K., Chicago, Ill.

abstract: ITHACA TWENTY‐FIVE years ago, some local craftsmen took the books off the shelves of the town library here and displayed their own works — and the town has never been the same. On Saturday, the customary tranquillity of the Ithaca College campus overlooking Lake Cayuga will be interrupted by the hustle and bustle of Craft Fair Ithaca. For a week, the works of more than 200 craftsmen from all over the state will be exhibited and sold at New York State's oldest craft fair.

abstract: FIVE KEYBOARDS Greenwich Village remains a music mecca, indoors and out, and visitors thronging the Sheridan Square area last weekend could have had a full evening of sidewalk listening alone. A Christopher Street crowd gathered for a woman cradling tape‐recorder accompaniment to her piercing Irish ballads. Over by the bank, two young men played Scott Joplin on a clarinet and flute. Down on Bleecker, a gospel quartet was drawing hearty applause, and up near 14th Street a student trio drew an ovation for Bach's second Brandenburg Concerto.

abstract: “I'm not tired at all — I feel strong,” said Mark (The Bird) Fidrych of the Lakeland Tigers yesterday after his third and longest effort in the Florida State League, where he is recuperating from tendinitis in his pitching shoulder. Fidrych threw 65 pitches Tuesday night, one more than his previous four- inning outing against Winter Haven, walked two and didn't allow a ball to be hit out of the infield. He is scheduled to pitch three innings on Saturday in Lakeland and return to Detroit on Sunday. If everything goes well, he'll start for the Tigers against the Texas Rangers next Wedenesday....Rivelino, the Brazilian soccer star, signed a twoyear contract with Al Hilal, a Saudi Arabian team. Although terms were not disclosed, Prince Halzoul Ibn Abdul Aziz, team president, said they were for $5 million to $9 million. He begins play on Sept.5.

abstract: Most miniature electric fans on the market today are those streamlined little things with a rotary blade that look just great but don't do much more than rustle the papers on one's desk. For those wanting more of a rush, Caframo Ltd., at Wiarton, Ontario, has come up with a new minifan guaranteed to really stir things up. Six inches high, six inches wide and 51/2 inches deep, the Caframo fan weighs only 1 pound, 10 ounces and has a twospeed motor housed in a small plastic case held aloft by a triangular wire frame. Although the blade of the fan is not covered, Caframo says that it is “absolutely safe” because it is made of a soft plastic. Available at Ad Hoc Housewares for $26.50.

abstract: PEKING‐HANOI TENSIONS RISE: Chinese leaving Vietnam because of alleged harassment wait at the border with China for official admittance into that country. Yesterday, China accused Vietnamese guards at the frontier checkpoint of forcing about 2,000 panic‐stricken refugees across the border by shooting into the air. The incident is likely to be discussed at talks between Chinese and Vietnamese officials next Tuesday in Hanoi.

abstract: Last Sunday, the worship was conducted outdoors, in the west yard of the Episcopal Church of St. Mark'sIn-The-Bowery, behind the fieldstone walls, the blackened steeple, the fallen roof and all the debris of the fire which so badly damaged that lovely church —179 years old — just days before. The Rev. David Garcia offered the mass and delivered the sermon. He said, “It is from tragedy that life comes, from ashes that resurrection begins.” The congregation sang, “If you walk amid the burning flames, you shall not be harmed.”

abstract: FLUORESCENT lighting fixtures have long been used in kitchens, laundry rooms, bathrooms and the like, but in recent years they have become increasingly popular for use in other rooms throughout the house because they are much more economical than incandescent lamps and because the tubes last much loneer than bulbs. A 40-watt fluo- rescent tube, tor example, will put out between four and five times as much light as a 40‐watt incandescent bulb and will last anywhere from six to eight times as long.

abstract: ed holds movement of regular Lebanese forces into south should increase credibility of Beirut regime and facilitate pacification and stability (M)
snippet: ed holds movement of regular Lebanese forces into south should increase credibility of Beirut regime and facilitate pacification and stability (M)
lead_paragraph: It is no great exaggeration to say that all that remains of Lebanon is a would‐be President, a would‐be Cabinet and a would‐be army of 650 men. The would‐be Government has now sent the would‐be army south to the region bordering on Israel to assert, if that is the word, a sovereign presence. It can do so not by the strength of its arms but only with the diplomatic consent of Syria and Israel. The question for them and other interested governments, like our own, is whether this banner is worth raising.

abstract: Extremely sentimental. We'll take our Lassie with more ginger and snap.
snippet: Extremely sentimental. We'll take our Lassie with more ginger and snap.
lead_paragraph: "THE MAGIC OF LASSIE," the latest ill-advised lulu at the Radio City Music Hall, begins with a song. James Stewart, playing the newest of Lassie's kindly old grandpas, leads two children in a number about "that hometown feelin'" and how wonderful life's simple virtues are. But in a movie in which the local grocery is a supermarket, the old-timey furniture is straight out of a Sears catalogue and the "bricks" by the hearth look like wallpaper, this kind of sentimentality is genuinely distressing. If anything, "The Magic of Lassie" is a testament to the creeping modernization of just about everything worthwhile. Even Lassie, who used to be just a smart, good-hearted and very, very clean dog, has developed the jaded manner of a veteran movie star.The ostensible villain of the piece is an evil zillionaire (Pernell Roberts), who means to steal Lassie, rename her "Heatherbelle," and annex Grandpa's land to his own vineyards. These lackluster ambitions give rise to a lackluster plot, but never mind — the real heavies are offscreen, creating a monster of a score. The songs, written by Robert B. Sherman and Richard N. Sherman, and sung by either Debby or Pat Boone, are not to be wished upon even that most cloying of creatures, the show-biz dog.It's a well-known fact that Lassie, now a direct male descendant of the original male collie (female collies supposedly have less photogenic coats), has some very special talents. He/she has sixth, seventh and eighth senses when it comes to returning home or retrieving lost children and kittens. And he/she can understand remarks made in English, replying with a hearty "Bark, bark!" from time to time.But until now, Lassie's gift for breaking into song (via voiceovers) had been largely unexploited. No more: This time, as Lassie wanders forlornly along a railroad track. Miss Boone supplies Lassie-ish thoughts in the background. Sample lyric: "I'm gonna get free by and by / I'm gonna get my patch of the sky."Then there are the numbers attributed to the little boy who has loved and (temporarily) lost his magical pet: "Lassie, my Lassie, I don't know why/But Lassie, I can't say goodbye." And, most reprehensible of all, there is the episode in which Lassie, having of course run away from his/her wicked new master, stumbles across the entire Mike Curb congregation in a country field, just as they happen to be rehearsing a big banjo number.To whom is all this a worse insult — the dog lover, the music lover, the child forced to sit through the film by a well-meaning relative, or the optimist who thought the Music Hall's reprieve might amount to something? Whatever your sentiments, the point is best argued at home.

abstract: ed comment on compliance with law in NYC
snippet: ed comment on compliance with law in NYC
lead_paragraph: It is heartening, during the morning dog‐walking hour, to see large numbers of New Yorkers complying with the new dog‐litter law — or at least armed with the tools for compliance. The obedience is not universal, and one group of malcontents went to court to try to overturn the law; but for the moment, there is a discernible desire to respect it or at least to test its force. So all of us — dog‐owners, dog‐lovers, dog‐haters and the indifferent — should applaud. It is one of those deli‐. cate moments of social experiment when every citizen's attitude can make a difference.

abstract: ed on Educ Research study; hopes, despite finding that smaller classes do not neccesarily mean better educ, that no one concludes study validates larger classes; notes study emphasized several educ areas in which students benefit from smaller classes (S)
snippet: ed on Educ Research study; hopes, despite finding that smaller classes do not neccesarily mean better educ, that no one concludes study validates larger classes; notes study emphasized several educ areas in which students benefit from smaller clas...
lead_paragraph: The common view of good schools is that children learn better in small classes than in large ones. Indeed, the private and suburban schools of the affluent point with pride to their success with small‐group instruction and are the envy of most other communities. But now a study by the Educational Research Service questions this faith. It has examined a variety of existing studies on class size and, without any new information, concluded that decades of research “fail to justify small, overall reductions in the class size or pupil‐teacher ratio.”

lead_paragraph: Predictably, the new television season will start before it officially opens. One network has made what the competing networks construe as a tactical maneuver, and it has been answered by the others with countermeasures. abstract: Boy sets out to recover his lovingly customized car. Silliness wins over whimsy, except in fine, cockeyed Vegas section.
snippet: Boy sets out to recover his lovingly customized car. Silliness wins over whimsy, except in fine, cockeyed Vegas section.
lead_paragraph: THERE isn't a line in "Corvette Summer" that doesn't read better than it plays. It's not just that Hal Barwood and Matthew Robbins, who make their respective producing and directing debuts, are best known as the screen-writing team responsible for "The Sugarland Express," "MacArthur" and "Bingo Long"; it's that they overstate scenes in a way they'd never dream of overwriting them.The central portion of "Corvette Summmer," set in Las Vegas with an "Alice in Wonderland" air, has a visual zaniness that meshes effectively with the script. But for the most part, the movie takes a slender, boyish conceit — of the sort that is suddenly so popular among Hollywood's current batch of boy wonders — and invests it with silliness rather than whimsy.Ostensibly, this is the story of a boy (Mark Hamill) and his car (a lovingly customized Corvette). In fact, it is the picaresque saga of a crazy, hopeless search, once the car is stolen and the boy sets out to recover it.The premise is not unlike that of "The Sugarland Express," in which a mother embarked on a long journey to recover her child, traveling across a landscape that seemed increasingly mad as the trip wore on. But Mr. Barwood and Mr. Robbins brought a wisdom to that earlier script that they deliberately eschew here, in the interests of a brand of juvenilia that simply doesn't suit them."Hal and I really aren't into cars, but we felt the Corvette was the perfect symbol for our story and our hero," Mr. Robbins is quoted as saying in production notes for the film. That's the trouble, right there: The movie seems to have been conceived in a fairly sophisticated spirit and then clumsily translated into kiddie-ese.Mr. Hamill, who had just the right insistent innocence for "Star Wars," is this time obliged to affect a naïveté that would be unconvincing in a tiny child. Annie Potts, as a would-be call girl he meets along his way, has Goldie Hawn's loopiness without the charm.Miss Potts may well be a gifted comedienne, but Mr. Robbins never lets her relax enough for the talent to show. Too often, he strains his actors' enthusiasm to the breaking point.Still, the middle of the movie is appealing, for anyone who can tolerate a mirthlessly nutty beginning and an ungainly shoot-'em-up finale. In Las Vegas, the half-mad buoyancy of Mr. Hamill's search for a four-wheeled Holy Grail finds an appropriately sun-baked setting, and Mr. Robbins's direction tackles pop culture with a gusto that resembles his hero's. It's a pity that the segment of the film that finally achieves a cockeyed conviction is so short-lived."Corvette Summer" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested") because Miss Potts's character makes no bones about what her new line of work is to be, and because of some very fleeting, dimly-lit nudity.
headline: {'main': "Screen: Saga of a Car In 'Corvette Summer':A Double Debut", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Screen: Saga of a Car In 'Corvette Summer':A Double Debut", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: NYC Council Pres Carol Bellamy introduces bill that would protect city employees from reprisals for reptg instances of corruption or mismgt in city agencies; measure would require city's Personnel Dir to monitor work record of so-called 'whistle-blower' for 2 yrs to ensure that no punitive action is taken against employee (S)
snippet: NYC Council Pres Carol Bellamy introduces bill that would protect city employees from reprisals for reptg instances of corruption or mismgt in city agencies; measure would require city's Personnel Dir to monitor work record of so-called 'whistle-b...
lead_paragraph: A bill was introduced in the New York City Council to protect city employees from reprisals for reporting instances of corruption or mismanagement in city agencies. The measure, introduced by Council President Carol Bellamy, would require the city's Personnel Director to monitor the work record of a so‐called “whistle blower” for two years to insure that no punitive action was taken against the employee.

abstract: Article on museum's Summergarden music program, sponsored by Mobil; illus (M)
snippet: Article on museum's Summergarden music program, sponsored by Mobil; illus (M)
lead_paragraph: THE time is around 8:30 on a recent Friday night. The place, the Museum of Modern Art's sculpture garden, which is filled with people deployed on the chairs, the steps and around the fountains. Informal but decorous, they recline in small groups on blankets spread on the ground with the occasional bottle and paper cups, or they sit, proclaiming their loneliness by sternly reading books. Rodin's “Balzac” supervises them from one side of the patio, Eli Nadelman's “Figure of a Hunter” surveys them from another. And from across the yard, a Despiau nude seems to regard the scene with an air ofinquiry. The trees tremble a little in the breeze.

abstract: Hollywood stunt men. Brisk, light entertainment.
snippet: Hollywood stunt men. Brisk, light entertainment.
lead_paragraph: "SMOKEY AND THE BANDIT," the Burt Reynolds movie that "Hooper" both follows up and improves upon, was a nationwide blockbuster and a washout in New York. The audience for "Hooper" won't be so neatly divided, and it may even be just as big. Mr. Reynolds is one of the most effortlessly appealing movie stars around, but consolidating his following has always been a problem: There are fans who like to watch him. tearing up the highway, and there are fans who enjoy his delightfully flippant self-mockery, with all the covert thoughtfulness it implies. This time, Mr. Reynolds has made a movie to please fans of all persuasions, and to please them a great deal.The title character, whom Mr. Reynolds plays, is the greatest Hollywood stuntman of his generation. Accordingly, he is sandwiched between the battered, ex-greatest stuntman of the previous generation (Brian Keith) and a fancy young newcomer (Jan-Michael Vincent) eager to give the old boys a run for their money. Watching Mr. Vincent dive off a skyscraper, Hooper and a friend remark, with a characteristic blend of malice and merriment, "Well, we probably could've done that when we were his age — 'cept they didn't have buildings that high."Hooper, who is working as stunt coordinator on a movie called "The Spy Who Laughed at Danger," sees retirement in the cards. So does his doctor: "If you were a horse, I'd shoot you," the doctor remarks, looking over the latest demolition job Hooper has done on his vertebrae. The presence of young, handsome and vigorous Mr. Vincent suggests the limitations time will impose on both Hooper's career as a glutton for punishment and Mr. Reynolds's as a matinee idol.But the film, while pensive enough to hint at these things, isn't so morose that it cares to dwell on them. It's far more interested in demonstrating — very convincingly — that making a movie can be more fun than almost anything else in the world.Mr. Reynolds and Hal Needham, who directed "Smokey and the Bandit," use the film-set milieu to generate some lovely in-jokes. At one point, Hooper is shown entertaining guests at a party with a reel of his favorite stunts, including some of Mr. Reynolds's own white-water work in "Deliverance." The guests are fast asleep.And then there is the highly unpopular director of the spy film, played with wonderfully humorless self-importance by Robert Klein. Concocting a finale that involves cars crashing into people in wheelchairs, buildings collapsing, explosions everywhere and a spectacular automobile jump across a river, the director is peeved to hear that his crew may not be able to execute all this. "I don't care. I want it!" he whines. "It's the ending I want. It's the statement I want to make." Later, when the elaborate scene is set up, Mr. Klein pronounces it to have "a nice grayness, like 'La Strada.'"In another scene. Mr. Klein shrieks something about movies being "pieces of time." For anyone unfamiliar with the title of Peter Bogdanovich's book of critical essays, let's just say that Mr. Reynolds has got even for "Nickelodeon" and "At Long Last Love."There is genuine humor and tenderness in Mr. Reynolds's romantic episodes with Sally Field, who plays Mr. Keith's very patient daughter, and there is real vitality in the large-scale action sequences. Also, Mr. Reynolds's generosity is particularly impressive. It's heartening to watch as scene-stealing an actor as Mr. Reynolds work this hard to make himself an ensemble player, just one of the boys."Hooper" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), largely because of the innocuous cussing that constitutes part of the stuntmen's camaraderie.

abstract: ABERGAVENNY, Wales—Chiseled on one of the structures of the Rockefeller Center in New York is the inscription “British Empire Building.” It is an historical curiosity, for the Empire which it commemorates, and which loomed so large in the world of the 1930's, when the Center was being built, is now no more than an equivocal memory. In its Victorian heyday the British Empire comprised nearly a quarter of the earth's land mass, and a quarter of its people. Today a few scattered islands are all that is left, and the glory is gone.

abstract: It's one entertaining thing after another this summer at Heckscher Park in Huntington, L.I., where events are scheduled daily through Aug. 20. This weekend is typical: the Orlando Ballet Company tonight at 8:30 (admission is $2); the Long Island Symphony Orchestra's free pops concert tomorrow at 8:30, with Anita Sheer, Spanish guitarist, and Luis Liciaga, Spanish folk dancer, and Sunday, Opera on the Sound's fully staged production of “La Boheme” at 8:30 P.M. (admission, $4). Seating is the same for all performances — blankets or chairs from home. From New York City, take the Long Island Expressway to Route 110; go north to Route 25A and continue on Main Street to Prime Avenue. Program information: (516) 271‐8923.

abstract: Ken Bode comment on Republican Party suit to overturn spending limits in Pres campaigns; holds suit has merit because present pol conditions make equal campaign resources amount to forcing Repubs into permanent minority status (L)
snippet: Ken Bode comment on Republican Party suit to overturn spending limits in Pres campaigns; holds suit has merit because present pol conditions make equal campaign resources amount to forcing Repubs into permanent minority status (L)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON‐The Republican national chairman, Bill Brock. obviously understands that money is a staple of politics and that changes in the laws regulating how much money can be raised and spent in campaigns can also produce shifts in the outcome of elections. He also believes that the current spending limits for Presidential elections — $21.8 million apiece for Jimmy Carter and Gerald R. Ford in 1976— amount to an unfair tilt against the G.O.P.'s Presidential candidate in 1980. So the Republicans have undertaken a lawsuit, hoping to persuade the United States Supreme Court to take another look at a part of the Federal Elections Campaign Act, which it already found to be constitutional two years ago.

abstract: As long as he lived, Fred Corcoran insisted that no golfer bad ever sunk a putt to win the United States Open. The championship has often been won by a single stroke, of course, and probably the last shot was always a putt, but on those occasions there were contenders still on the course who had to lose before the winner's victory would be established. Fred contended that no player had ever addressed his ball on the final green knowing that the putt would give him the Open, and had run it down. In the Desert Classic, yes; in the Sports of The Times Doral Invitational, sure. But never in the National Open. Never in Fred's lifetime,. that is. The great golf promoter, historian and raconteur died last year, and it wasn't until this year that a golfer sank a putt to win the Onen

abstract: Ed scores HR vote to break UN embargo on trade with Rhodesia; says amendment could undermine what chance remains for Carter Adm to bring warring forces into transitional coalition
snippet: Ed scores HR vote to break UN embargo on trade with Rhodesia; says amendment could undermine what chance remains for Carter Adm to bring warring forces into transitional coalition
lead_paragraph: It is hard to know what the House of Representatives thought it was doing this week when it voted to break a United Nations embargo on trade with Rhodesia as soon as the present triumvirate of black and white factions have themselves anointed by elections of their own design. We can find only two messages in the measure: (1) to Prime Minister Ian Smith and his black associates: Hang on; do not negotiate with the leaders of the Patriotic Front guerrillas; the relief Western recognition and trade resumption is on the way; (2) to the guerrillas: There's no point maneuvering for a military impasse that might lead to negotiations; as soon as elections with no guarantee of fairness to your people are held, we shall freeze you out; so you might as well do your best to disrupt the elections.
headline: {'main': 'From Bad to Worse on Rhodesia', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'From Bad to Worse on Rhodesia', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: AREA A — Despite recent bad weather, fishermen in this area are still reporting good catches of bluefish. Action has been lively 10 to 15 miles off Margate, N. J., in 70 or 80 feet of water where Hopkins lures and bucktails have proved most productive. Closer to shore, schools of blues in the 2‐to 4pound range have been caught with tube‐type lures. Blues have also been abundant south of Sandy Hook, with party boats reporting catches up to 12 pounds. In Great Egg Harbor Inlet, fluke catches have been averaging 3 pounds on minnows and cut bait. Weakfishing in the inlet also has been picking up in recent days for fishermen using cut bait.
lead_paragraph: AREA A — Despite recent bad weather, fishermen in this area are still reporting good catches of bluefish. Action has been lively 10 to 15 miles off Margate, N. Blues have also been abundant south of Sandy Hook, with party boats reporting catches up to 12 pounds. In Great Egg Harbor Inlet, fluke catches have been averaging 3 pounds on minnows and cut bait. Weakfishing in the inlet also has been picking up in recent days for fishermen using cut bait.

abstract: The Boston Red Sox, who reached town in the throes of their worst slump of the season, left early today with revived spirits and batting averages after two rainy nights in Yankee Stadium — just when their three pursuers in the American League East were closing for the kill. their revival apparently came in the nick of time, because the division is now entering a kind of August free-forall involving the four top teams. In fact, during the next 11 days the Red Sox and Yankees will play 18 games against their chief rivals, the Milwaukee Brewers and Baltimore Orioles.

abstract: Fashion photographer in jeopardy. Swank but erratic whodunit. You'll guess who soon enough.
snippet: Fashion photographer in jeopardy. Swank but erratic whodunit. You'll guess who soon enough.
lead_paragraph: DEAD men in evening clothes; supine women guarded by sleek, ferocious dogs; upside-down corpses wearing garter-belts, with their hair and makeup in exquisite disarray — these are the tricks of Laura Mars's trade, the hallmarks that have established her as the New York fashion photographer who outkinks them all. However, not everyone is a fan. Someone has gotten the notion that there's evil in Laura's work, he/ she/it has decided to wipe out the photographer plus all her super-hyper-ultra chi-chi friends.So far, very good indeed — especially because the "Eyes of Laura Mars" audience is given ample opportunity to share the killer's pique. Laura (Faye Dunaway), being much too self-involved an artiste to worry about the implications of her work, merely thinks of herself as someone who gives "an account of the times in which I'm living," times rife with "moral, spiritual and emotional murder."Questions about the exploitative aspects of her art merely prompt Laura to snap, "Look, does anyone have anything positive to ask?" The models she works with are even more trendily blase.These models are almost certainly being set up, deliciously, during the early parts of the film. They giggle, chew bubble gum, have pet teddy bears, don't seem to know when they're wearing clothes and when they aren't, and date rich idiots when they aren't making eyes at one another.When Laura's whole crew is hauled into a police station for questioning, one of the girls is irate at being treated like a hooker, even though she's more than dressed for the part. Another merely complains of being bored.A couple of Laura's shooting sessions, staged with a delightful blend of nonchalance and depravity, epitomize the wickedly satirical edge of this lively, high-toned thriller.While two cars are aflame in Columbus Circle, and models in lingerie and fur coats prettily smack each other around, Laura, bless her creative little heart, is all business, solemnly snapping away in a Theoni Aldredge creation. Occasional cuts to spectators in the street make it clear that Laura may well have just arrived from the planet for which she is named, as far as workaday Joe or Joan America is concerned.However, right in the middle of the session Laura has a psychic flash, something that neither she nor the movie needs.Laura can witness killings taking place across town, but only from the unseen killer's point of view — the better to forestall a surprise ending that is altogether dumbfounding (with the emphasis on dumb). These flashes leave her understandably frantic, but Laura has already been established as too much of an amoral flake to arouse much sympathy in her lady-in-distress capacity.But forget the faltering finale, and never mind about a score that, although it includes Barbra Streisand's smashing rendition of the theme song, also makes the killer's forays even more ominously heralded than Bruce the Shark's.It's the cleverness of "Eyes of Laura Mars" that counts, cleverness that manifests itself in superlative casting, drily controlled direction from Irvin Kershner, and spectacular settings that turn New York into the kind of eerie, lavish dreamland that could exist only in the idle noodlings of the very, very hip.René Auberjonois brings his full supply of comic prissiness to the role of Miss Mars's principal artistic whatch-amatcallit, and Raul Julia makes her ex-husband a brooding loon, hence a good suspect.The best supporting performance comes from Brad Dourif (who played the young suicide in "One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest"), as an ex-con who epitomizes both the movie's taste for voyeurism and its essential seediness. Mr. Dourif, whose bedraggled appearance and half-unhinged manner make it hard to believe he would ever have been hired to carry Miss Mars's lens caps, has been given the job of chauffeur by Mr. Auberjonois, for shady reasons we will never know.Mr. Dourif's awe and fear at what he witnesses during the course of a typical Mars day is the keenest commentary the movie has to offer. His tiniest gestures are noteworthy. Miss Dunaway is perfect for her role, but it's beginning to look like the only role she cares to play.Hysterical jitters, countered by fits of extreme hauteur or assertiveness, have constituted so many of her recent performances that it's hard to remember what else she can do. In any case, high-minded artistic fluttering — the kind Diane Keaton attempts in "Interiors" — comes so naturally to Miss Dunaway that Tommy Lee Jones, as a down-to-earth, soothing cop, is not just a good foil but an indispensable one. Without his stabilizing presence, the movie might well have turned into a "Network" set in the netherworld.A footnote: Miss Dunaway has lately had to play some of the worst-written love scenes on the block, and "Laura Mars" gives her another clinker of this ilk. When she and Mr. Jones embrace at long last, she says "It's terrifying." He says "It's beautiful." She was right the first time.

abstract: John Russell selects his favorite works from 6 public collections in NYC; collections are the Frick, Hispanic Soc of Amer, Bklyn Museum, Thannhauser collection of Guggenheim Museum, Modern Art Museum and Met Museum; illus (L)
snippet: John Russell selects his favorite works from 6 public collections in NYC; collections are the Frick, Hispanic Soc of Amer, Bklyn Museum, Thannhauser collection of Guggenheim Museum, Modern Art Museum and Met Museum; illus (L)
lead_paragraph: IN every great permanent collection of art there is something that speaks to each of us imperiously and will not yield to the competition. Here is one critic's choice of just, a few such works from six public collections in New York. City. To make a choice of this kind we have to follow our own private instinct, even if that runs contrary to the fundamental rhythm that every great institution sets up for itself. Every such institution has such a rhythm. Most often that rhythm is beaten into us by the Grand Staircase.

snippet: leaves Paris for Washington after 10-day trip to West Africa (S)
lead_paragraph: In his first appearance before a Congressional subcommittee since he retired from the Senate in 1975, Sam J. Ervin Jr. said yesterday that Congress “has no powir to amend the past” by extending the seven‐year limit established .for state legislatures to ratify the equal rights amendment. Mr. Ervin, who opposed the amendment in 1971 when he was in the Senate, testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on the Constitution in the Old Senate Caucus Room, where he presided over the televised Watergate hearings five years ago. “The power to fix a reasonable time for state action on a proposed constitutional amendment must reside in the Congress :that submits it,” said Mr. Ervin. “It cannot be determined retroactively by a subsequent Congress. The 95th Congress has power to legislate for the future. It has no power to amend the past.”

lead_paragraph: “I think that the physical characteristics of the Spofford Juvenile Center exhibit our schizophrenia about what Spofford is,” Beverly Sanders, Assistant Commissioner of the Human Resources Administration for Special Services for Urban Affairs Children, said in a recent interview. “When you go through the place, you'll see big, heavy, locked doors that you open with huge keys, and then you'll see nice win- dows with small screens that you could just push right out before they were reinforced.”

abstract: Grand Duke, The (Operetta): Rev of Light Opera of Manhattan production
snippet: Grand Duke, The (Operetta): Rev of Light Opera of Manhattan production
lead_paragraph: GILBERT and Sullivan collabo rated on “The Grand Duke” in 1896. It was the last operetta they were to write, and it was a failure. It disappeared for good, from the repertory of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company and from the reportories of various offshoots in England and America. Thus it is of more than unusual interest that tne Light Opera of Manhattan has revived this virtually unknown work. Those who love the G.&S. operettas — and who doesn't?—will want to make up their own minds about the merits of the work, and Light Opera of Manhattan is now giving them a chance.

abstract: ed suggests that Ticcinini and Giordano should be put to work filling potholes (S)
snippet: ed suggests that Ticcinini and Giordano should be put to work filling potholes (S)
lead_paragraph: Street crime has fallen to a new low, to judge by the report from Newark. Two men there are charged with stealing a street, by pulling up its 12‐pound Belgian paving blocks, one at a time. The thievery went on for a period of weeks; the men are accused of removing some 50,000 blocks, and selling them for $21,000. Wiseacres may be tempted to wonder about what the road to hell is now paved with, or how to curb criminal instincts, or whether the defendants cornered the pavingblock market. Such impulses might be directed toward devising a punishment that fits the crime. What strikes us about the case is the culprits’ audacity in thinking that motorists hereabouts are so inured to bad roads that they wouldn't even notice the absence of paving. The just sentence seems obvious to us: put ‘em to work filling potholes.

lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 3 (UPI) — paper workers’ union threatened today to extend its strike to seven Crown Zellerbach Corporation plants this week. The union is on strike at 17 other West Coast mills.

abstract: Tomboy passed off as noble's granddaughter. Entertaining caper.
snippet: Tomboy passed off as noble's granddaughter. Entertaining caper.
lead_paragraph: IF this were a world of perfect logic, the arrival today in neighborhood theaters of "Candleshoe," the latest Walt Disney production, would be an occasion of calculable joy not among children but among the elderly.For "Candleshoe," with its beguiling English countryside settings, languid pace, defanged Dickensian villains, compassionate butler, down-at-the-heels nobility, hidden treasure and orphaned children engaged in a plot to outwit swindlers, keep up appearances and save the old manor from foreclosure, is the fiction of a bygone era.The chords it sounds, with its evocation of a world of stately homes, formal gardens, family heirlooms, titled women, eccentric ancestors, perfect servants, tea parties, steam engines and classic motorcars can resonate within an older generation in a way they never can among children whose cultural touchstones are more likely to run the gamut from Big Bird to The Hulk to John Travolta and the Bee Gees.The values "Candleshoe" — espouses — kindness, consideration, good manners, sacrifice for the sake of others, pluck in the face of odds — were, too, the overt moral currency of a society that long antedates Watergate, Koreagate and the Me Generation.So entering the world of "Candleshoe," which is based on the Michael Innes novel, "Christmas at Candleshoe," is like taking a trip in a time machine. Within the terms of its plot, Jodie Foster, a delinquent foster child up to no good in the streets of Los Angeles, is whisked off to a Tudor mansion in Warwickshire, a journey that seems more a vault across generations than across distance.There, ostensibly in league with a blustering villain inspired by Dickens and played by Leo McKern, she is to try to pass herself off as the long-missing marchioness, heir to the estate; and she is to endeavor to find a hidden treasure, whose existence is known only to McKern and Vivian Pickles, who portrays his sister, a servant discharged from Candleshoe.And who should be the kindly current mistress of Candleshoe? Why none other than Helen Hayes, who has taken in a few orphans from the overcrowded local children's home. And who should be the perfect butler, the feisty Scottish gardener, the tippling chauffeur and the old colonel who takes tea with old Lady Gwendolyn? Not four people, but one — David Niven, doffing and donning wigs and mustaches and eyebrows and various articles of clothing in league with the orphans to keep Lady Gwendolyn from knowing that time and the taxman have reduced her circumstances to a point of peril.The cast is beyond reproach. In this summer when Hollywood seems to have concluded that box-office magic lies in setting its best young actresses down in England, Miss Foster as Casey Brown easily keeps pace with Tatum O'Neal as Sarah Brown (could they be related?) in "International Velvet." Miss Hayes, Mr. Niven, Mr. McKern and Miss Pickles comport themselves with their customary professionalism.There's a new Walt Disney movie in town. Kids, take grandma.

abstract: editorial says Bar Assn should recognize importance of televising courtroom proceedings
snippet: editorial says Bar Assn should recognize importance of televising courtroom proceedings
lead_paragraph: In a century of existence, the American Bar Association — sometimes called the “organized bar” has had proud moments, as when it worked to rescue legal services for the poor from a Nixon Administration bent on destroying them. It has had moments when it ought to have been spanked, as when it took stands against no‐fault insurance. And there have been times of utter confusion, as in its sluggish, negative response to price competition and advertising. Whether or not the A.B.A. represents the profession — half the nation's 460,000 lawyers are now members — it certainly reflects the best and the worst that lawyers represent.

lead_paragraph: In April 1975, then‐Secretary of the Treasury Willimb E. Simon led a delegation of United States officials to the Soviet•Union to discuss trade matters. At the conclusion of the two‐day meeting, the American group boarded Air force Two for the trip home. As the jet lifted off and the 80 passengers realized they were no longer on Soviet soil, the group spontaneously burst into applause. For Mr. Simon, it was a most poignark demonstration of the sense of freedom.

snippet: Aviocolli Eva: NYS Sup Ct Judge Hyman Barshay sentences Bartolomeo Peppe to 25 yrs to life for murder of Aviocolli (S)
lead_paragraph: Bartolomeo Peppe, 45 years old, who shot the woman he was living with to death on March 3d in front of her daughters, 8 and 9 years old, was sentenced yesterday to 25 years to life in prison by Justice Hyman Barshay in State Supreme Court in Queens. The victim was Eva Avicolli, who was slain in her apartment at 4219 18th Avenue, Borough Park, while Mr. Peppe's two sons, aged 11 and 13, held back the victim's two girls.

abstract: Sam Hardage, unsuccessful candidate for US Sen seat, is seriously injured when private plane crashes, Aspen (S)
snippet: Sam Hardage, unsuccessful candidate for US Sen seat, is seriously injured when private plane crashes, Aspen (S)
lead_paragraph: ASPEN, Colo., Aug. 4 (UPI) — Sam Hardage, a businessman and unsuccessful candidate for the United States Senate seat in Kansas three days ago, was seriously injured when his private plane crashed on landing at the Aspen airport late yesterday. The authorities said that Mr. Hardage, 39 years old, who finished third in Tuesday's nine‐way Republican Senate primary, was airlifted to a hospital in Denver, 150 miles east of Aspen, with a possible skull fracture, facial lacerations and internal injuries.

abstract: Race‐track regulars have their version of the old joke about the brain transplant. The tout who sells victims on the idea of getting one displays a wide variety of choices: a $50,000 brain left by a successful businessman; a $100,000 specimen formerly owned by a distinguished lawyer; an even larger brain, costing $250,000, from an internationally famous scholar. Finally, the tout points to a freezer containing a tiny brain with a price tag of $500,000.

abstract: Will air program that is last TV performance of comedienne Totie Fields (S)
snippet: Will air program that is last TV performance of comedienne Totie Fields (S)
lead_paragraph: The admiring stare of Britain's 18year‐old Prince Andrew proved to be so disconcerting for Gianetta Baril, a 17year‐old harpist, that She broke a sixth octave string on one of the last notes of Handel's Passacaglia at a banquet for Queen Elizabeth II in Edmonton, Alberta. The flustered Miss Baril's embarrassment led the Queen to give her son a public reproving frown and, apparently, a private motherly scolding. Andrew, who had been sitting at a table near Miss Baril during the perfortnance, consoled her afterward about breaking the string. “Mum's blaming it on me,” he said.

abstract: A leading British politician was arrested and charged, with three other men, of conspiring to murder a former male model who claimed to have had homosexual relationship with him. The man arrested, Jeremy Thorpe, was formerly leader of Britian's Liberal Party. The claim by Norman Scott, the former model, led to Mr. Thorpe's resignation as the party leader in 1976. Mr. Thorpe, 49 years old, remains Member of Parliament and of the Privy Council. [Page 1, Column 5.]

lead_paragraph: FORT MADISON, Iowa, Aug. 4 (AP) A propane gas line running through a parched cornfield in southeastern Iowa exploded today, killing two elderly persons, injuring six and destroying a twostory farmhouse, the authorities said. abstract: ST. PAUL, Minn. — Two years ago, Robert Schroeder, a shipping clerk at the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company here, strained his liack on a warehouse loading dock. abstract: BAGUIO, THE PHILIPPINE
lead_paragraph: BAGUIO, THE PHILIPPINE How would Anatoly Karpov, the world champion, or Viktor Korchnoi, the challenger, stack up against Bobby Fischer? It has been almost six years since Fischer won the world championship from Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union in Rejkjavik, Iceland, and all this time he has secluded himself in his Pasadena apartment. In 1975, Fischer lost his title by default to Karpov when he refused to play under the match rules set by the World Chess Federation.

lead_paragraph: ASHLAND, Ore. — Jerry Turner, the producing director of the Oregon Shakespeare Festival, is worried. abstract: The good sloop Clearwater, which has been spreading its environmentalaction message for a decade now, pulls into the Huntington town dock (New York Avenue, Halesite) today at 2 P.M. to start a 10‐day journey through North Shore waters. A duplicate of a 19th‐century Hudson River sloop, the 106‐footlong ship will spend two days at each of four ports of call, inviting Long Islanders aboard for traditional folk music concerts, three‐hour‐long sails and inspection tours.

abstract: Yachting. abstract: Tuesday, weather permitting, the 16½ acres of Central Park's Sheep Meadow will be covered with blankets, chairs and close to 150,000 people. The occasion will be the New York Philharmonic Orchestra's first concert in the parks this summer. Andre Kostelanetz is slated to conduct the allTchaikovsky program, which concludes with the “1812 Overture” and accompanying fireworks display. Friday night the same program can be heard at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, and again on Saturday in Queens at Cunningham Park. There are three other programs including Wagner, Berlioz and Mahler that New Yorkers can enjoy out of doors, with the final concert to be conducted by Zubin Mehta on August 29. (See Music)

abstract: Sophocles, Oedipus the King (Book): Translation of Steven Berg and Diskin Clay revd by Bernard Knox; illus
snippet: Sophocles, Oedipus the King (Book): Translation of Steven Berg and Diskin Clay revd by Bernard Knox; illus
lead_paragraph: WITH the publication of these two volumes, the Oxford series “Greek Tragedy in New Translation” is roughly one‐third of the way along its course: 11 down, 21 to go. It is a distinguished enterprise; on the whole, the translators have amply satisfied the demand of the General Editor, William Arrowsmith, for “language, rich and vivid as poetry” which “is equally effective as dialogue actors can speak, naturally and with dignity.” The project has even higher ambitions: “Its aim is to re‐create the entire extant corpus of Greek tragedy as though it had been originally written by ancient masters at home in the English language of our time.” This is a job for poets, and though there are a surprising number of Greek scholars who are also published poets (six of the 11 translations have only one name on the title page) the work often has to be done, as in the case of the two Sophoclean tragedies under review, by a poet in collaboration with a scholar.

abstract: The Commerce Department's index of leading economic indicators rose moderate four‐tenths of a percent in June, but most of that increase was “artificial,” caused by a rush for building permits in California before new, stringent energy conservation requirements were imposed on new buildings. The index, which tends to foretell future economic trends, was essentially unchanged in May…. Other signs that economic growth may be more sluggish in the remainder of 1978: New factory orders dipped three‐tenths of percent in June, and sales of new domestic cars in‘july eased off the heady pace of May and June. Detroit reported sales gains of only four‐tenths of a percent in last month's final 10‐day selling period from the year‐earlier period although for the full month deliveries were 4.2 percent better that in 1977… Prices received by farmers for their goods fell for the first time in nine months, according to the Agriculture Department. The 1 percent decline won't immediately affect retail prices for food, said department experts, who noted in a separate report that consumers can expect a 10 percent increase in food prices in 1978. The department had originally estimated that increase at percent.

abstract: Roy Radin's Vaudeville '78: Article on 9-act variety show that has brought together veteran performers in vaudeville format; producer Roy Radin, George Jessel and Donald O'Connor comment; illus; performers listed (L)
snippet: Roy Radin's Vaudeville '78: Article on 9-act variety show that has brought together veteran performers in vaudeville format; producer Roy Radin, George Jessel and Donald O'Connor comment; illus; performers listed (L)
lead_paragraph: From Pompano Beach, Fla., to Tampa and St. Augustine, to Norfolk, Va., and to Akron, Ohio and Lorraine, to Johnstown, Pa., Wheaton, Md., Portsmouth, R.I., to New Bedford, Mass., and Manchester, N.H., the InterCounty bus rented in Babylon, L.I., had zigzagged, one‐nighting just about all the way. For 31 days — and 27 cities —the land cruiser had been the vaudevillians’ main base, a mobile family room of sorts where packs of plastic cups, thermoses of coffee, coolers filled with soft drinks and beer, packages of potato chips and cookies, enough books for a village library, needlepoint, suit and dress carriers and blankets and pillows lay in overhead racks and on and over the seats.

abstract: Just Representations: A James Gould Cozzens Reader revd by John Chamberlain
snippet: Just Representations: A James Gould Cozzens Reader revd by John Chamberlain
lead_paragraph: TN his introduction to this commemorative 75th birthday selection from the works of James Gould Cozzens, Matthew Bruccoli tells us that he about to present a relatively forgotten man. It is not that Cozzens has suffered from lack of exposure (after all, he had six Book‐of‐the‐Month Club selections, Pulitzer Prize, a William Dean Howells Medal and couple of Hollywood adaptations in what he calls his post‐apprenticeship novelistic career). But his major books — “The Last Adam”(1933), “Men and Brethren”(1936), “The Just and the Unjust”(1942), “Guard of Honor”(1948), “By Love Possessed”(1957) — do not appear on college reading lists that are chockablock with Cozzens’ contemporaries, and the English faculties tend to ignore him.

lead_paragraph: CLARKSVILLE ASIGN on Route 1 in this Mercer County community reads, “Beefalo — World's Best Grass Converter.” A beefalo is not a farm implement, as you might think, but a hybrid animal that is a cross between a cow and a buffalo.
