abstract: 12 top US fashion designers teamed up to create 1,200 costumes for $22 million movie The Wiz; illus; designers cited (L)
snippet: 12 top US fashion designers teamed up to create 1,200 costumes for $22 million movie The Wiz; illus; designers cited (L)
lead_paragraph: It started because director Sidney Lumet wanted the segment to be all about “status and style.” It ended up with Oscar de la Renta, Bill Blass, Mary McFadden, Ralph Lauren, Halston, Norma Kamali, Stephen Burrows, Scott Barrie, Zoran, Ronald Kolodzie, Fernando Sanchez and furriers Alixandre and Ben Kahn producing the costumes that help turn the Emerald City scene in the Universal‐Motown film “The Wiz,” due in October, into a razzle dazzle spectacular. While the star, Diana Ross, gets to wear only one simple white blouse and skirt through two hours or more of film, 400 beautiful black dancers get to preen and prance for 10 minutes — changing costumes three times — in original creations by these top fashion talents. The result is an unforgettable extravaganza (for instance, the moment when 20 handsome male dancers hoof it up in impeccably tailored Ralph Lauren tuxedos — of gold lame). It is also a salute to American design talent. The idea came from Joel Schumacher, screenwriter of “The Wiz,” and, according to most of the designers, it was because of his enthusiasm that they agreed to do it. They were given color swatches and $200 for each costume— a pittance compared to the average $1,000 it takes to produce a single sample. Each design was made three times — once in emerald green, once in red and once in gold. Everyone had a field day. Some, like Halston, refused to use inexpensive theatrical fabrics and sent costumes made of stuff costing $100 a yard and more. Bill Blass's arrived with his usual custommade touches. Fernando Sanchez cut short a Paris holiday to personally drape each dress. Said Norma Kamali, “When we finished, we all had tears in our eyes. We had enjoyed it so much.” “All of them made a great contribution of time, talent and money.” says Joel Schumacher. As for the costumes themselves, alas, they will go the way of all chorus‐line clothes — to the storerooms of Universal Studios to be reworked for some other film or just fade away, their magic preserved only for 10.

snippet: Possibility that sport may be legalized in NJ discussed; econ benefits noted; dog racing has been fastest-growing sport in US in past 10 yrs; illus (M)
lead_paragraph: IN 1934, the last year there was dog racing in New Jersey, promoters of the fledgling sport came up with the awful idea of using monkeys to ride the greyhounds. The public was understandably repelled by the simian jockeys, who were finally banned from the track, but the sport never recovered; the bill legalizing it was found to have been unconstitutionally drafted, and dog‐racing was banned only four months after it had begun.

abstract: JERUSALEM — Hopes for peace. in the Middle East soared dramatically high last November when Egyptian President Anwar el‐Sadat suddenly flew to Jerusalem. But since that dazzling ascent, there has been a stage‐by‐stage decline, from the early face‐to‐face conferences of Mr. Sadat and Prime Minister Menachem Begin, through bilateral negotiating committees to triangular meetings under United States sponsorship. Now it's back to where it started, with a harassed American Secretary of State shuttling between capitals.

abstract: THE TROPICS — Panama is a country one usually visits on the way to somewhere else, going north or south by plane or east or west by ship. But it is well worth coming to Panama for its own sake either for a few days’ rest and fun or for an entire vacation. There's the canal; there are casinos, and there are beautiful, beaches on offshore islands. And more than anything else, there is the tropical ambience — the heat and humidity, the noise and rhythms, the rain forests that seem to grow before one's eyes, the relaxed laughter of many races living in harmony. Those who dislike noise should keep to the islands or that strip of Middle America, the Canal Zone. But that is to miss the real flavor of Panama.

Now it's got a lot less of one very important element — money — in part because of the way the package attempted to please. abstract: Article on voyage on Chesapeake Bay aboard shipjack schooner; illus; diagram (M)
snippet: Article on voyage on Chesapeake Bay aboard shipjack schooner; illus; diagram (M)
lead_paragraph: The captain of a passing pleasure craft fixed us with an appraising eye, then broke into an appreciative grin as his 35‐knot twin‐diesel fiberglass sports cruiser flashed by while we cleared Sandy Point and entered Chesapeake Bay. He swung around in his cushioned chair on the flying bridge, raised a bullhorn and electronically bellowed across the waters: “You're looking mighty pretty, Lady Katie.” • me praise was for our 65‐foot skipjack, the Lady Katie, classic sloop that has been restored to almost mint condition. She is one of the last of her class to prowl the bay and the only one available for charter.

abstract: Alexander, Sidney: Marc Chagall revd by James R Mellow; por
snippet: Alexander, Sidney: Marc Chagall revd by James R Mellow; por
lead_paragraph: SIDNEY ALEXANDER'S Chagall is not the Sunday‐supplement artist: not simply, that is, the 91‐year‐old patriarch of modem art, survivor ancient cultural battles; nor the Jewish artist, storyteller par excellence, whose fables of old Russia, full of floating pedlars and bridal couples, fiddlers on the roof, sacrificial cows and symbolic goats, ghetto villages and moonstruck streets, have charmed generations; nor the international celebrity of recent years whose important commissions — including ceiling paintings for the Paris Opera, murals for the New York Metropolitan Opera, stained‐glass windows for the Synagogue of the Hadassah Hebrew University Medical Center outside Jerusalem — have brought him a glossy fame and considerable wealth.

lead_paragraph: The most serious threat to television and its claim to First Amendment freedoms is not the Federal Communications Commission or the Supreme Court or an Imperial Presidency, but the runaway television rating process. The current obsession with surveying the “habits” and “pulse” of television sets, rather than the response of and impact on human beings, has resulted in an industry preoccupied with short‐term indicators and profits at the expense of its own long‐term promise and economic stability.

abstract: Bethel, Pepsi, Authentic Jazz Dance Theater: Biog and career sketch of dancer Pepsi Bethel on occasion of forthcoming performance of group as part of Clark Center Dance Festival revd (L)
snippet: Bethel, Pepsi, Authentic Jazz Dance Theater: Biog and career sketch of dancer Pepsi Bethel on occasion of forthcoming performance of group as part of Clark Center Dance Festival revd (L)
lead_paragraph: The accompanist was up to double time, and two by two, the class charged across the studio in a series of leaps and long steps. A small, slight black man with a cap of gray hair and a body that could be described as near‐Cubist — all edges, angles and indentations — stood to one side, shouting out the beat and pounding a tambourine. As the last pair finished, Pepsi Bethel dropped the tambourine and launched a run of his own, tacking on a couple spins, a fancy shuffle and a high kick at the end. Laughing, the students did their best to follow; moments later, at the class's conclusion, they broke into a spontaneous ovation that lasted half a minute.

abstract: Book The Oxford Book of Oxford, compiled and edited by Jan Morris, revd; work brings together 8 centuries of comment on univ and its denizens; drawings (L)
snippet: Book The Oxford Book of Oxford, compiled and edited by Jan Morris, revd; work brings together 8 centuries of comment on univ and its denizens; drawings (L)
lead_paragraph: APART from the monarchy, few institutions in England emerged earlier than Oxford and Cambridge. They are, for example, older than Parliament — very early in the 12th century, indeed by 1117, there were scholars at Oxford. Since then Oxford has grown like a coral reef — buffeted at times by the rage of religion, the clash of civil war and the anger of social envy but, like the monarchy, adapting to social change, to the demands of new economic and political worlds, even if slowly. No matter how tumultuous the times, no matter how powerful, passionate, resentful those bent on reform might be, Oxford preserved an exceptional independence and cherished an elite.

abstract: Anybody in musical journalism learns, soon on, approach first‐performance claims, especially of works by old composers, with a large amount of caution. Nobody keeps accurate records along these lines, and those who go off halfcocked are sure to be brought to the bar. Say, for instance, that you run a small opera company and have round “Dido Abbandonata,” a forgotten work by Giovanni Battista Pierluigi. You look up the “Handbook of American Operatic Premieres” by Julius Mattfeld (No. 5 in the Detroit Series of Musical Bibliography, in case you are interested) and you find no entry. You check with Maria Rich of the Central Opera Service. She has never heard of any performance in America. You ask around, and nobody has ever heard of any performance. Hell, they have not even heard of the composer. So you announce “Dido Abbandonata” as an American premiere. Sure enough, you are going to get a letter from the Lower Chaminade Society of East Cattleboro, Iowa, complete with photostat of program, saying ha, ha, we staged this on Feb. 12, 1902.

lead_paragraph: DOROTHEA LANGE was endowed with most of the acceptable stigmata of the certified genius, photography division. Ambitious, of course, with a flair for fame, hard on herself and others, alter.; nately (but always theatrically) kindhearted and inconsiderate, implacably egotistical, domineering, contentious, apparently humorless, self‐analytical ad nauseam, hard‐working to the point of total exhaustion — even death—she appears to have been like most great photographers, a pain in the neck.

lead_paragraph: The script lay unopened on the table. Soon, The Legend would enter a soundproof booth and begin reading into a microphone the words typed for him, making them come to life with a cadence like the rise and fall of a roller coaster. But now there was the matter of the can of coffee and the half‐eaten doughnut. Pondering them, The Legend reached lazily for the doughnut, then drew back his hand. It was still early in the morning, too early to grab the day. The Legend looked tired. His eyelids were marshmallows.
headline: {'main': 'Allen, Legend Still: How About That?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Allen, Legend Still: How About That?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Article on work of Holly Nichols in attempting to save Amazon parrots on West Indian island of Dominicia from extinction: illus (L)
snippet: Article on work of Holly Nichols in attempting to save Amazon parrots on West Indian island of Dominicia from extinction: illus (L)
lead_paragraph: Two large black shadows appear suddenly in our peripheral vision. Looking up quickly through binoculars, we see brief, brilliant flashes of red, yellow, green. A pair of parrots returns, screeching, to the outer branches their nesting tree. They quickly vanish from sight amid the confusing play sunlight and shadow in the dense tronical foliaee ne parrots are silent now. My companion explains in a whisper that they are making their way — slowly, secretively, so no predator can follow ward toward the trunk of the tall hardwood tree. Their nest is there, concealed from our view by a tangle of huge ferns, vines and air plants.

lead_paragraph: A new executive director, Bernard C. Fisher, is taking office for the 35‐year‐old Citizens Committee for Children of New York Inc., Aug. 14. Mr. Fisher has most recently served as assistant executive director andNew York area director for the State Board of Social Welfare. Elizabeth If. Wolff, the advocacy group's president, said he would immediately try to promote increases in social services to welfare childrep, in line with a committee study that charged that 600,000 such children were being given “short shrift” in New York City. Other priority projects, she said, involve juvenile justice, health and child care.

abstract: Former students, anxious to find places in publishing world, reflect on popular trade paperbacks at Radcliffe's 31st annual Publishing Procedures course (M)
snippet: Former students, anxious to find places in publishing world, reflect on popular trade paperbacks at Radcliffe's 31st annual Publishing Procedures course (M)
lead_paragraph: Tempest on the Charles. The voices that drift through Harvard's halls in midsummer are usually temperate and reasonable, as befits an ancient seat higher learning. They were that way last month as 80 carefully selected men and women, all recent college graduates, all anxious to find places in publishing, forgathered in the Gutman Library for the daily sessions of Radcliffe's 31st annual Publishing Procedures course. They listened with the earnestness of neophytes about to take religious orders as a score of editors, authors, printers and marketing specialists explained what the life they aspired to would be like. Some particularly relished the protest of John Irving, author of “The World According to Garp,” that book publishing is fast being “Hollywoodized.”

abstract: In the foreword to “Inventive Paris Clothes 1909‐1939: A Photographic Essay by Irving Penn” (Viking / Studio, $18.95), the great fashion photographer says he was inspired by “A luxurious clothes‐world (that] had once existed (and not so long ago at that), apparently without concern for cost, where it seemed no material was too expensive to use, no amount of labor too dear to employ, no designer's fantasy too extravagant to realize.” The clothes from the Costume Institute collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art are by Poi ret, Vionnet, Molyneux, Chanel, Schiaparelli and others. The text and captions by Diana Vreeland, special consultant to the Costume Institute, are as sumptuous as the garments themselves. The Callot dress on the left, with its floating panel train, is of coup de velour, edgedwith silver lace.

abstract: “Baby, that is rock and roll” sang the Coasters in 1959, and nobody had to ask what they meant. Rock and roll had defined itself since it burst upon the national consciousness in the mid‐1950's. According to Chuck Berry. it had a backbeat you couldn't lose. According to Jerry Leiber and Mike Stoller, whc wrote the Coasters’ hit, you couldn't always understand the words; if you did, “You'd really blow your lid.” Accord. ing to a leaflet distributed by White Citizens Councils in the South, “the screaming, idiotic words and savage music of these records are undermining the morals of our white youth in America,” but on the whole this warning was not greeted with the serious consideration it merited.

lead_paragraph: HARTFORD IN 1838, when she was 27 years old, Harriet Beecher Stowe wrote to friend: “I have about three hours a day in writing, and if you see my name coming out everywhere, you may be sure of one thing, I do it for the pay. have determined not to be a mere domestic slave without even the leisure to excel in my duties. I mean to have money enough to have my house kept in the best manner.”

abstract: EAST HADDAM
lead_paragraph: EAST HADDAM AS the saying goes, there is good news and bad news at Geiston House in East Haddam. First the good news. The 19th century Victorian house in which the restaurant is ensconced is a beauty, inside and out, and handsomely maintained. Each dining mom is nristinelv done in period style. The entire effect makes an attractive complement to the neighboring Goodspeed Opera House, another Victorian delight located just a skip away on a hillside overlooking the Connecticut River. Lunch or dinner at Gelston House before a performance at Goodspeed could make an appealing outing to this nicely preserved summer town on the river.

abstract: Exhibit Aspects of Realism at Guild Hall in East Hampton revd by D L Shirey; illus
snippet: Exhibit Aspects of Realism at Guild Hall in East Hampton revd by D L Shirey; illus
lead_paragraph: EAST HAMPTON WHEN realism started yet another comeback more than a decade ago, it was generally greeted in the art world with a shrug of indifference. Most of the comebacks of the last 30 years were unsuccessful. Was there any reason to believe that this one wouldn't be like the others, a shortlived phenomenon? The feeling in certain art circles was that realism had burned itself out, offering few new important possibilities, and that abstraction still held most of the artists in its powerful grip.

abstract: Sheila P Long lr on rev (S)
snippet: Sheila P Long lr on rev (S)
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I find it ironic that Caroline Seebohm, in her review of William Arnold's “Shadowland” (July 2), fails to mention Mr. Arnold's principal source Frances Farmer's autobiography, “Will There Really Be a Morning?” (Putnam, 1972). The reviewer would have had less praise for Mr. Arnold's “tragic detective work” had she read Miss Farmer's own graphic account of her five‐year imprisonment in the violent ward of Western State Mental Hospital. Miss Farmer describes, in poignant detail, the tortures of insulin shock, hydrotherapy and brutal incarceration: She was kept naked and caged in a “pen” for incurables; she witnessed a lesbian rape that left its victim mutilated and catatonic. At one point, she was forced by a guard to eat her own excrement. Few prisoners have undergone such hellish torment. Yet she not only enduted: she survived the inferno to write a stirring autobiographical account of her experiences….

abstract: James Carroll's “Mortal Friends” hasn't been banned in Boston. To the contrary, the city seems to have taken to its heart the 35‐year‐old author of the bestselling novel about the Boston Irish and the Irish Irish. “Here, ‘Mortal Friends’
lead_paragraph: James Carroll's “Mortal Friends” hasn't been banned in Boston. To the contrary, the city seems to have taken to its heart the 35‐year‐old author of the bestselling novel about the Boston Irish and the Irish Irish. “Here, ‘Mortal Friends’ is taken as a really Bostonian book,” Mr. Carroll said recently in a telephone conversation from his home “on the down side of Beacon Hill.” Mayor Kevin White himself introduced the author at a lecture. “It embarrassed me to admit my world was not Boston.”

abstract: Lerner, Gerda: A Death of One's Own revd by Helen Yglesias
snippet: Lerner, Gerda: A Death of One's Own revd by Helen Yglesias
lead_paragraph: FOR some, the most terrifying aspect of death that it will not yield to being managed; these are often the best of people, who strongly believe the attractive possibility that human existence can be arranged into an orderly, harmonious and peaceful communality. From Gerda Lerner's beautifully controlled account of her husband's death, it would appear that she and Carl Lerner were lust such vigorously optimistic realists. The kind of courage with which they faced the ravaging disaster of an inoperable brain tumor, given the tragic combination of indomitable character and violent circumstance, makes for a book that heartens and breaks the heart at the same time.

lead_paragraph: Outwardly, the National Ballet of Canada and the London Festival Ballet would seem to have little in common. The implicit model for the Toronto company has always been Britain's Royal Ballet and devotees of that company have never considered Festival Ballet to be in the same class. At times, Festival Ballet hat even been regarded as the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo of the British Isles. Today, its repertory and plethora of dancers from throughout the world bring it closer to such American troupes as the Joffrey Ballet and American Ballet Theater than to the National Ballet.

abstract: If the ideal string quartet is democratic musical partnership in which four compatible, firstrate players perform together as if on a single instrument, the Cleveland Quartet has come close to that ideal these past few years. In fact, ever since the quartet was formed nearly a decade ago, violinists Donald Weilerstein and Peter Salaff, violist Martha Strongin Katz and her husband, cellist Paul Katz, have built a reputation for giving the kind of performances that steadily win high critical praise and the approval of chamber‐music devotees.

lead_paragraph: WHEN Mount Kisco and Newcastle cooperatively embarked on the process of reassessing their taxable properties last year, they were the first two Westchester communities to walk that pitted path toward assessing property at 100 percent of its market value. mere 131 of the 991 New York State communities had preceded them in this effort dictated by state law and court decisions and invariably they had incurred the wrath of their residents. lead_paragraph: DOUBLEDAY threw a large party the other day for people in the trade and for assorted literati to celebrate the completion of renovations of its flagship store on Fifth Avenue between 56th and 57th Streets. Joseph Heller, Louis Auchincloss, William F. Buckley Jr., Ethel Merman and Irwin Shaw were among those who sipped assorted beverages, nibbled flavorsome tidbits, oohed and aahed over the decor and fashioned bon mots for the press. A fascinating if silent presence at this gathering was the new elevator, whose stainless steel machinery is now visible. It moved up and down its shaft as ominously and soundlessly as those sharks that have been getting so much attention in the bookshops these days.

snippet: Article on Natl Playwrights Conf, Waterford, Conn; conf, more generally called the O'Neill Festival, offers intensive confrontation of playwrights with their plays in attempt to strengthen playwrights; illus (L)
lead_paragraph: Shakespeare had his own theater. So did Molière, Ibsen and Strindberg. Shaw did not produce plays, but as a theater critic for three years, he got to know the life and machineries of the working theater at next to first hand. The performed play is the third dimension the written one. Knowing what happens to your words in actors’ mouths, knowing what an imagined movement will when tramped out by real people, deciding what complexities will survive when they are played — all this is essential to the playiright.

abstract: Our colleague, M. A. Farber, sits in jail because the courts feel their prerogatives and procedures take precedence over a full airing of his urgent constitutional case. He must remain behind bars indefinitely —while he and The Times are also fined heavily — because he wrote about some mysterious deaths in a New Jersey hospital a decade after they occurred and refuses to disclose to the murder trial that ensued who told him what and when. The New Jersey courts deny stay of sentence unless his confidential files are revealed to them in private — which would betray his case even if his argument later prevailed. Two Supreme Court justices refuse to second‐guess their New Jersey brethren and are divided on the merits.

abstract: Article on ideological split between natl and local Republican candidates notes split on 'Proposition 13' type tax cuts; natl candidates support concept, while local condidates worry about how to finance their adms (L)
snippet: Article on ideological split between natl and local Republican candidates notes split on 'Proposition 13' type tax cuts; natl candidates support concept, while local condidates worry about how to finance their adms (L)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From the Capitol to Kansas, two Republican Parties were on display last week, almost as different from each other as from the Democrats. In Washington, clean‐cut Representative Philip M. Crane of Illinois, the hope of the New Right, announced for the Presidency, pledging “a free people liberated from excessive government.” In Toneka, bearded Gov. Robert F. Bennett, who said he deserved re‐election because he kept taxes down and expanded state aid, won the primary after preaching nothing more ideological than Jefferson on “that government is best that governs least.”

abstract: The prospect of dining out alone nightly in foreign restaurants has probably deterred the departure of more incipient single travelers to Europe than any other contingency. While it is not true that 15 years of Freudian analysis are needed before one can dine out singly with a reasonable sense of well being, the background of a very good military school plus the fortification of a certain amount of alcohol are viable substitutes.

abstract: Israeli Labor Party leader Shimon Peres holds best solution to territorial question is Palestinian entity under Arab flag; outlines history of Israeli-Arab conflict; illus (L)
snippet: Israeli Labor Party leader Shimon Peres holds best solution to territorial question is Palestinian entity under Arab flag; outlines history of Israeli-Arab conflict; illus (L)
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM—The differences between the Labor Party and the Herut Party involve both domestic and foreign affairs. World opinion is mainly concerned with our debate on international issues. Israel is an authentically democratic country and its foreign policy is decided by the majority. We, in the Labor Party, are for the time being out of power. Yet, on some basic issues there is something like a national consensus. Israelis are divided on strategy and method, not on the aim of peace itself. Both coalitions, that of the Government and that of the opposition, reject the creation of a separate Palestinian state between Jordan and Israel. We know that it would be militant, chronically hostile and dangerous to the security and peace of Jordan and Israel alike. Such a state would also bring a strong Russian influence into the heart of our land, at the gates of Jerusalem itself.

snippet: Kerr, Jean: How I Got To Be Perfect revd by Phyllis Theroux (M)
lead_paragraph: JEAN KERR is one of the first women to hitch herself up to a typewriter and spin the straw of her not completely suburban existence into publishing gold. She is now, as she was back when her children were eating the daisies, an intelligent, irreverent, articulate writer, and her latest book is exactly what the public has come to expect of her. Exactly.

abstract: Comment on life and work of French Impressionist painter Camille Pissaro on occasion of publication of Kathleen Adler's book Camille Pissaro: A Biography; illus (L)
snippet: Comment on life and work of French Impressionist painter Camille Pissaro on occasion of publication of Kathleen Adler's book Camille Pissaro: A Biography; illus (L)
lead_paragraph: Camille Pissarro was one of the finest human beings who ever touched a brush. He never said an evil word. He never harbored an evil thought. Nothing was too much trouble for him when it came to helping a fellow artist. He worked till he dropped. He had his full share private misfortune and bore it in exemplary style. He was very well read, and he put his reading to good use. His letters were a contribution to literature, though he would have been the last person to say so.

lead_paragraph: Downstairs at the International Center for Photography (1130 Fifth Ave., at 94th St.), the main gallery is filled with grand and glorious photographs of Western scenery, most of them taken since 1950 by such photographers as Minor White and Paul Canoninro as well as by others less familiar. This is the first part of exhibition entitled “The Great West: Real / Ideal” (through Sept. 3), and the tone is set by two of Ansel Adams's heroic vistas of spectacular mountain scenery with dramatic lighting and atmospheric effects.

abstract: They were true folk heroes of the turn of the century — the threshermen who came calling at America's farms at dawn. Moving across rich earth, transforming every wheatfield they traversed, the threshermen rode majestically in astride chuffing steam engines that literally made the harvest happen. And they brought an energy and an excuse for teamwork that made their visits seem like Christmas, Thanksgiving and July 4th rolled into one.

abstract: A fairly wide band of clouds extends all the way from Nova Scotia to the South Atlantic States, then westward to Arkansas. Showers and thunderstorms are spread out along this frontal zone with cooler air to then north and warm, muggy air to the south. Individual strong thunderstorm clouds can be seen over the Gulf of Mexico and across the Bahamas and Florida. Light showers are moving into the northern Rockies.

abstract: rehearsals with Meryl Streep and Raul Julia described; drawing (L)
snippet: rehearsals with Meryl Streep and Raul Julia described; drawing (L)
lead_paragraph: M eryl Streep and Raul Julia are rehearsing “The Taming of the Shrew” seated on two studio chairs in a rehearsal room at Joseph Papp's Public Theater. Act II, Scene 1, when Kate and Petruchio meet and clash for the first time. Miss Streen has Kate's skirts hiked un — revealing two red kneepads she's wearing for protection — and the Puerto‐Rican born Mr. Julia is blowing away Petruchio's lines like so many dandelion seeds. “She swings as sweetly as the nightingale,” he says. Then stops.

abstract: Dr Joan Ullyot article on marathon swimming focuses on Diana illus (M)
snippet: Dr Joan Ullyot article on marathon swimming focuses on Diana illus (M)
lead_paragraph: This week, the world is watching with fascination and admiration as Diana Nyad prepares for an attempt to set record for the longest open‐water free swim ever: from Cuba to Florida. Speed is of only secondary interest in this effort. Miss Nyad's main problem is how to keep her muscles moving, propelling her 103 miles across the Gulf Stream, for an estimated two and a half days. If she succeeds, hers will be the greatest sports endurance feat ever, by a man or a woman.

abstract: Rabbi David I Golovensky article replies to Medoff's article; says it lacks balance and perspective; says Westchester is home of thriving and dynamic Jewish community; illus of Marc Chagall painting (M)
snippet: Rabbi David I Golovensky article replies to Medoff's article; says it lacks balance and perspective; says Westchester is home of thriving and dynamic Jewish community; illus of Marc Chagall painting (M)
lead_paragraph: IWELCOME with some reservations Randy Medoff's assessment [Westchester Weekly, July 2] of the Jewish identity crisis among American Jewish youth, especially in Westchester. It is abundantly clear Mat American Judaism is faced with urgent challenges. The plunging birthrate and galloping intermarriages, accompanied by malaise and apathy among many Jewish youths, are taking a mounting toll and sapping the vitality of the Jewish community.

snippet: Hunterdon Art Center's Natl Print Exhibit at Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences revd by D L Shirey; illus
lead_paragraph: MORRISTOWN WHY is printmaking attracting so many artists these days? Painters who usually express themselves in oils or acrylics are trying their talents in woodcuts, etchings, intaglios and other forms of prints, and sculptors who usually mold shapes out of bronze, marble, steel, plastics and other materials are doing the same thing. And then there are the “pure” printmakers, those who make nothing but prints.

abstract: Ladune, Emmanuel Le Roy: Montaillou: The Promised Land of Error revd by Raymond A Sokolov
snippet: Ladune, Emmanuel Le Roy: Montaillou: The Promised Land of Error revd by Raymond A Sokolov
lead_paragraph: JACQUES FOURNIER, Bishop of Pamiers in the south of France in the early 14th century (and later Pope Benedict XII) was a grand and skillful inquisitor. He was determined to extirpate the last traces of the Albigensian heresy from the Pyreneean village of Montaillou, where it was gasping its last after centuries of Catholic persecution elsewhere France and Italy. A wily interviewer, Fournier wormed extremely full confessions out of Montaillou's shepherds and smallholders, wives and maids. Furthermore, the Bishop kept such good records that today, when the precise tenets of the Albigensian heresy are in doubt, a modern historian has been able to extract an astonishingly complete picture of daily life and culture in the Montaillou of 1320 from Fournier's transcript..

abstract: WHEN the extraterrestrials decide to get touch with us, as the film “Close Encounters of the Third Kind” so vividly demonstrated, they will not have to tap into the President's red phone. Nor will they need to send out for a Billy Graham or a Muhammad All td'act as spiritual intermediary. No, they will simply transmit into the ether the notes of an ordinary diatonic chord, one only slightly more complex than the door chimes that signal the arrival of the Avon Lady, and we will all snap immediately to attention. You snicker at this simplehearted conceit, but the myth of a universally understood musical language is deeply rooted and has always struck a sympathetic chord in popular fancy. Politicians called upon to address international gatherings invoke this cliché as if Dr. Pavlov had rung their bell. Their audiences accept it implicitly, too, even though a dozen radically different musical cultures may be represented among the listeners. A few jaded musicians and musicologists may smile, but ancient cliches do not wither away under the disdain such as they.

abstract: There is an argument to the effect that the most interesting dishes to work with in any cuisine are those whose character can be changed at will, the changes limited only by imagination and taste. One of the great foods summer feasting fits that definition precisely — cold stuffed eggs. The ings are literally without end. Cold cubed chicken. ham, turkey, veal, and poached fish can be used, garnished with anchovies, olives, pimentos and other kindred edibles. The sweet herbs are virtuous: parsley. chives. tarragon, chervil, even rosemary. The egg yolks. sieved or blended, are generally bound with mayonnaise and/or butter. Add a bit of salt and pepper and your creativity can take it from there. Here are four of the various fillings.

abstract: John Z Kiss lr on Bakke decision (S)
snippet: John Z Kiss lr on Bakke decision (S)
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The development of test‐tube babies can be compared to the perfecting of wing transplants so that pigs might fly: an impressive academic exercise which could lead to useful knowledge, but which in itself can only be called unnecessary. We could regard it with the detached admiration considered appropriate in every scientific advance (even one whose value is not immediately apparent) were not its implications so malevolent.

abstract: Swift, Edward F: Splendora revd by Anne Tyler
snippet: Swift, Edward F: Splendora revd by Anne Tyler
lead_paragraph: THE courthouse in Spiefidora, Tex., is an antique red‐brick building with gables and turrets and gothic windows and a four‐faced clock, but all this is encased in a jerrybuilt modern cover‐up three concrete blocks that rise in tiers like a blank wedding cake. And Timothy John Coidridge, a onetime Splendora boy of legendary beauty who vanished without a by‐your‐leave some 15 years earlier, is long last returning to Splendora, but he's returning as Miss Jessica Gatewood, a refined librarian of 33 who dresses in late Victorian style and wears her hair in Gibson Girl topknot.

abstract: Commuters walking in and out of Grand Central Terminal were able to view spectacular color transparency of an African scene. This breathtaking photograph spanned most of the width of the station (a distance of more than 60 feet) and was made from a single color slide measuring a little less than an inch by an inch and a half! It was as much a tribute to the photographer Ernest Haas, as it was to the wizardry of Kodak's scientific team and the quality of the Leica camera and lens that recorded it.

lead_paragraph: JEREMY BERNSTEIN has one invaluable attribute for a science writer. It is not that he is professor of physics (at the Stevens Institute Technology), although that must be a considerable help; nor that he writes primarily for The New Yorker, although that must be a pleasure. It is that he able to write clearly, transparently, about subjects as opaque as quantum theory and molecular biology. Mr. Bernstein's prose disappears and the content shines through.

abstract: $12-million regional water system in Warren County dedicated; system was developed by Soul City, creation of Floyd McKissick, and neighboring communities; McKissick comments (S)
snippet: $12-million regional water system in Warren County dedicated; system was developed by Soul City, creation of Floyd McKissick, and neighboring communities; McKissick comments (S)
lead_paragraph: It was not an impossible dream, just improbable: That was Floyd McKissick's enterprise in black capitalism to build a new town called Soul City in Warren County, N.C. Only 50 families now live in Soul City, so there is much to be done before the dream takes shape. That it is a realizable dream, however, was evident last week at the dedication of a $12‐million regional water system, developed by the city's managers and neighboring communities, and financed by local, state and Federal funds. About 80,000 residents of Warren, Vance and Granville Counties will draw about ten million gallons of water a day from the system. Controlled electronically and backed up for emergencies by a diesel‐powered generator, the system is what Mr. McKissick describes as “the part of our infrastructure essential for growth and development.”

abstract: Travel attractions of Cold Spring described; Plumbush restaurant cited; illus (L)
snippet: Travel attractions of Cold Spring described; Plumbush restaurant cited; illus (L)
lead_paragraph: CONSIDERING its distinguished neighbors, Cold Spring, in the southwest corner of Putnam County, should be household word. It not only looks across a splendid stretch of Hudson onto the West Point Military Academy and Storm King Mountain, but also borders on first‐rate hiking trails, is two miles from the Boscobel restoration, and is the site of the highly regarded Plumbush restaurant. But though it seems to slumber, a bypassed river town on a bygone “cold spring,” it stirs with signs of a new awakening.

abstract: Sex and crime are a volatile combination, especially in politics. For years, Jeremy Thorpe, former leader of Britain's Liberal Party, has been dogged by allegations that he had a homosexual relationship with Norman Scott, a onetime male model. The second ingredient for a first‐rate political scandal was added last week: Mr. Thorpe and three political friends were charged with conspiring to murder Mr. Scott, a crime for which Mr. Thorpe could be sentenced to life imprisonment. The homosexual insinuations, which he has consistently denied, forced Mr. Thorpe to resign the Liberal leadership in May 1976, but he held on to a seat in Parliament and was widely respected for his statesmanship. A witty speaker with a gift for mimickry, he was sometimes called “the last of the Edwardians” because of his manner but also for his attire that often included a homburg, waistcoat and heavy watch chain. Now his parliamentary career, and the Liberal Party's dwindling fortunes along with it, are greater jeopardy.

abstract: Tired of paddling that canoe? Grumman Boats offers three kits that allow you to adapt a canoe for sailing, rowing or motoring. The sailing rig consists of a 55‐square‐foot sail, a leeboard, a kick‐up rudder and a Bendy three‐piece, 16‐foot aluminum mast; it sells for $400, and a smaller version is available for $350. The rowing attachment, consisting of a seat for the rower and supports for the row locks, can be clamped to the gunwales with a screwdriver and pliers; that costs $75. A $23 bracket, adjustable to fit most canoes, can hold a small outboard to ease a long or upstream trip; Grumman recommends a quiet five‐horsepower electric motor. For catalogues and the addresses of dealers near you, write to Grumman Boats, Marathon, N.Y. 13803.

snippet: Ed urges Sen ratification of Internatl Convention on the Prohibition of Mil or other Hostile use of Environmental Modification Techniques; cites rept by US Weather Modification Bd to Commerce Sec Kreps on possibilities for weather manipulation and...
lead_paragraph: Mark Twain's observation that everybody talks about the weather but nobody does anything about it, hasn't been true for 30 years. It was in the mid‐1940's that Vincent J. Schaefer first demonstrated how to seed clouds with dry ice to produce precipitation. Since then, innumerable experimenters have found Ways todisperse tog, shrink hailstones and otherwise to defend against unfavorable weather. A start has been made, but scientists are still far from understanding all the forces that determine climatic, changes and certainly far from the ability to control them.

abstract: Study by Center for Research on Act of Man, headed by Dr Samuel Z Klausner, finds that many of assumptions about welfare recipients are wrong and thus Fed welfare and employment policies rest on invalid premises; study's findings detailed (M)
snippet: Study by Center for Research on Act of Man, headed by Dr Samuel Z Klausner, finds that many of assumptions about welfare recipients are wrong and thus Fed welfare and employment policies rest on invalid premises; study's findings detailed (M)
lead_paragraph: Some assumptions about welfare recipients, memorialized in Congressional testimony and in executive branch studies, have formed conceptual foundations for public policy. Among the more powerful of the assumptions, which are not necessarily consistent, are the notions that welfare recipients are aberrationally unemployed, that they are isolated and unmotivated, that they do not work because they are lazy, and that the men leave home to increase the family's welfare income. A study on the subject was recently completed for the Department of Labor by the Center for Research on the Acts of Man. It was headed by Dr. Samuel Z. Klausner, a University of Pennsylvania sociologist, and suggests that many of the assumptions about welfare recipients are wrong and thus that Federal welfare and employment policies rest on invalid premises.
headline: {'main': 'Study Finds Some Prevalent Ideas About Welfare Families Incorrect', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Study Finds Some Prevalent Ideas About Welfare Families Incorrect', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: All the Governor's men had thought they were done for the day. That was what the day's official schedule had said, but as it turned out, the official schedule meant no more than the day's official speeches, which had not been delivered. And sothey found themselves sitting at a corner gasoline station somewhere in Nassau County, in weather wittingly warm, being informed that after Belmont Race Track, Long Island Jewish‐Hillside Medical Center and a reception in Garden City, Mr. Carey had decided to move on at 7 P.M. on a Friday night to an unscheduled stop at an Italian feast in Glen Cove.

abstract: PAWLEY'S ISLAND. S.C.
lead_paragraph: PAWLEY'S ISLAND. S.C. IFOUND myself, early one morning recently, standing in a tidal marsh, chest deep in water, my feet sinking slowly into the muddy bottom, while I grasped one end of large net with one hand and used theother to swat away horseflies that seemed only slightly smaller than sparrows. What I was doing in this rather awkward position was trying to catch shrimp, and I soon discovered they are a lot shiftier than they appear to be when served up on a bed of lettuce and crushed ice.

abstract: Ed backs Fed Reserve bid to charge member banks for banking services (S)
snippet: Ed backs Fed Reserve bid to charge member banks for banking services (S)
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve System is a mighty institution. Its chairman is one of Washington's most powerful individuals and its impact on the economy, through the manipulation of credit and interest rates is immediate and far‐reaching. It is surprising, therefore, to find that some people are deeply worried about the Fed's abiding strength. In the the oast eight years. 430 smalland medium‐sized banks have left the Fed System become state‐chartered banks. To put its finger in the dike before too many more of the remaining 5,668 banks slip away, the Fed has proposed a profound change in the way the national banking system operates. It wants to pay member banks interest on the $38 billion of reserves they must hold and to charge these members for services now provided free.

abstract: H C Schonberg comment; notes petition for landmark status; lists some great performers who concertized in hall and bemoans lack of farewell gala; drawing (L)
snippet: H C Schonberg comment; notes petition for landmark status; lists some great performers who concertized in hall and bemoans lack of farewell gala; drawing (L)
lead_paragraph: PERHAPS it was inevitable. institutions come and go. Now it is Town Hall's time. The venerable (by New York standards) concert and lecture hall will close on Aug. 31, perhaps for good. Not with a bang, not even with a whimper. There will he nn great farewell evening on the stage that has been graced by the likes of Fritz Kreisler, John McCormack, the Budapest Quartet, Lotte Lehmann, Sergei Rachmaninoff, Elisabeth Schwarzkopf. Nobody is rising in wrath, as concerned people did when the future of Carnegie Hall was threatened. At least on Sept. 12, at 10:30 A.M. in City Hall, admirers of Town Hall will ask the Landmarks Commission to keep the auditorium as a national treasure.

lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 — An attorney for James Earl Ray, the convicted killer of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., said today that the House Select Committee on Assassinations had violated the law and its own rules as a part of a “conspiracy” to prevent a fair investigation of the assassination, which took place in Memphis 10 years ago. m ne lawyer, Mark Lane, said in a statement issued here that the committee's investigators and their agents had suborned perjury, criminally received stolen property and monitored and taperecorded telephone conversations.

lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 8 (AP) — A leading Anglican churchman in the Botswana district was released yesterday after being held in South African police headquarters since July 26, according to The Johannesburg Star. The Rev. MiChael Molale, 45, was arrested at an airport in Johannesburg. He was formerly a priest in the black townships of Sharpeville and Soweto and has been active in assisting South African refugees in Botswana.

abstract: GREENWICH, CONN.
lead_paragraph: GREENWICH, CONN. THERE'S a world of conflict beneath the blanket of tranquillity that covers the woodsy‐country house of Bill and Barbara Williams in what the local gentry call back‐country Greenwich. Beyond the perception of the uneducated eye, the house is surrounded by a struggle for survival that confounds the errant pavementpounder who has dropped in and divines only an almost disturbing serenity in the chirpy silence. It is peace that seems to preclude the street dramas perennially waiting to be played out on the sidewalks of New York.

abstract: newspapers in the Northeast worried as strike against Great Northern Paper Co enters 6th wk; strike has closed huge mill that produces about 1/4 of all newsprint used in New Eng; spokesman for Capital Newspapers, Hearst group in Albany, NY, says entire Hearst chain could face supply problems if strike goes on for very long (S)
snippet: newspapers in the Northeast worried as strike against Great Northern Paper Co enters 6th wk; strike has closed huge mill that produces about 1/4 of all newsprint used in New Eng; spokesman for Capital Newspapers, Hearst group in Albany, NY, says e...
lead_paragraph: As their supplies of newsprint grow tighter, newspapers in the Northeast are keeping an anxious eye on a strike against the Great Northern Paper Company, which yesterday entered its sixth week. The strike. against the subsidiary of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation, has closed the huge mill in northern Maine that produces about one‐quarter of all the newsprint used in New England. The surprise action was the first at the company inmore than 70 years.

abstract: Royal Manhattan Hotel is sold to investment group headed by Paul Milstein that hopes to convert 1,400 rooms to apts; purchase price is $2.5 million; illus (M)
snippet: Royal Manhattan Hotel is sold to investment group headed by Paul Milstein that hopes to convert 1,400 rooms to apts; purchase price is $2.5 million; illus (M)
lead_paragraph: The Royal Manhattan Hotel, which has been closed since 1974, has been sold to an investment group that reportedly hopes to convert its 1,400 rooms to apaitments.. The purchase price is said to have been $2.5 million. beverai persons familiar with the transaction said that the investment group is headed by Paul Milstein, who recently paid close to $30 million for two operating midtown hotels, the Biltmore and the Roosevelt. Mr. Milstein could not be reached for comment.

abstract: Vietnamese Prime Min Pham Van Dong tells Amer delegation in Hanoi that country wants not only reconciliation with US, but also normalization of relations and 'friendship'; delegation brings out of Vietnam 19 children and 10 wives who had been separated from Amer fathers and husbands since war's end; delegation member Archbishop Philip M Hannan says Vietnam will accept assistance, especially food and medicines from official and private sources (M)
snippet: Vietnamese Prime Min Pham Van Dong tells Amer delegation in Hanoi that country wants not only reconciliation with US, but also normalization of relations and 'friendship'; delegation brings out of Vietnam 19 children and 10 wives who had been sepa...
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 7� — Prime Minister Pham Van Dong of Vietnam told an American delegation sent to Hanoi by Senator Edward M. Kennedy that his country wanted not only a reconciliation with the United States, but also normalization of relations and “indeed friendship'between the two nations. ne delegation arrived here today after a week's stay in Vietnam. It brought out of the country 19 children and 10 wives who had been separated from their American fathers and husbands by the Communist victory in 1975. The 29 will be taken to the United States for the first Vietnamese‐American family reunification.

lead_paragraph: Health maintenance organizations (H.M.O.'s) offer medical services for a fixed annual fee. They are cheaper than conventional, fee‐for‐service care because, with their income predetermined, they have no incentive to order unnecessary treatment, tests or hospitalization. The Carter Administration has heartily enctorseci me concept as consistent with its national health‐insurance and cost‐containment goals and has backed legislation sponsored by Senators Kennedy Massachusetts and Schweiker of Pennsylvania to increase the level of Federal support.

Javits said yesterday, announcing that he will enter Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center today for surgery to repair a damaged nerve in his right elbow. The nerve has oeen ‐punisneo by well over 50 years of tennis,” said the 74‐year‐old Senator. He said that he would be in the hospital's Harkness Pavilion for three days. lead_paragraph: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 7 — Most parodies, like most poems, are low‐level wit, easy to dismiss with an embarrassed laugh. But above and beyond the Mad magazine variety of lampoon there is a more serious kind of joking, which in its finest form can be devastating to its object because it is written from the inside of a tradition, with ‐mingled disrespect and affection. That was the level to which Dennis Eberhard's “Parody,''a work for soprano and chamber ensemble, seemed to be aspiring last night at Tanglewood.

abstract: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 7 (AP) —A grand jury today returned a murder indictment against 18‐year‐old Edward Falby of Westport in the slaying of 9 year‐old Karl Jo Spurkeland, whose body was found near her Westport home June 13. abstract: Ed scores HR Judiciary subcom bill on sovereign immunity that would substitute US rather than individual officials as defendants in damage suits; holds bill fails to adopt disciplinary provisions to punish official agreed to by Justice Dept and ACLU (M)
snippet: Ed scores HR Judiciary subcom bill on sovereign immunity that would substitute US rather than individual officials as defendants in damage suits; holds bill fails to adopt disciplinary provisions to punish official agreed to by Justice Dept and AC...
lead_paragraph: America began life amid denunciations of King George as a tyrant, but it has clung, ever since, to the doctrine of sovereign immunity — “the King can do no wrong.” In its extreme form, this doctrine immunizes government against suits to redress even the most outrageous violations of citizens’ rights. The idea is that even democratic governments must be free to do the public business without being subject to harassing lawsuns. bo government can be sued only when it agrees be sued, which is not often. The problem is one of balance: how to deter, remedy and punish wrongdoing without inhibiting the process of government.

Aug. 7 — The judge in the “Born Innocent” trial ruled today that in order to collect damages from the National Broadcasting Company the plaintiff must actually prove that the network intended viewers to imitate the violent rape scene in the television movie. he ruling was a decisive First Amendment victory for NBC and raised the strong probability that the case will be dismissed tomorrow, with the agreement of both sides, to give the plaintiff a chance to seek an appellate court review of the judge's order.

abstract: SILVERSTONE, England, Aug. 7 (AP) — Kenny Roberts of the United States was confirmed late yesterday as the winner of the British 500cc Motorcycle Grand Prix. The race was interrupted when heavy rain led some riders to stop to change to wet‐weather tires. When they got back to the track, officials did not know their positions. After Roberts was originally declared the winner, Britain's defending world champion, Barry Sheene, protested, as did other riders.

abstract: Article on significance of upcoming FTC and FCC investigations into quality of TV ads aimed at children; drawing (M)
snippet: Article on significance of upcoming FTC and FCC investigations into quality of TV ads aimed at children; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: Although it has been under a constant barrage of criticism for years, television advertising aimed at children has generally managed to stay out of the political arena. But no more. Two reuerai regulatory agencies are zeroing in on such ads, and the gathering storm is likely to have wide implications for the television industry, advertisers and perhaps even the regulatory process itself. The. Federal inquiries could lead to severe restrictions on TV advertising to children and, conceivably, even to an outright ban.

abstract: US League of Savings Assns repts avg acct with saving and loan assns in '77 had balance of $5021 and earned $300 annually in interest; says 77 million accts exist within total deposits of $387 billion; notes 12% increase in deposit totals over previous yr (S)
snippet: US League of Savings Assns repts avg acct with saving and loan assns in '77 had balance of $5021 and earned $300 annually in interest; says 77 million accts exist within total deposits of $387 billion; notes 12% increase in deposit totals over pre...
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) — The average person with an account at a savings and loan institution had a balance of $5,021 at the end of last year, a trade association said today. The United States League of Savings Associations said the balance included interest payments averaging $300. There were about 77 million savings and loan accounts with $387 billion in deposits at the end of the year, the organization said. That was an increase of about 13 percent in deposits from the end of 1976.

abstract: Few players have any particular reason to remember their first duplicate game, but Jill Slater of Staten Island will surely be among that number. She was a winner at a Tuesday afternoon game at Snug Harbor, the setting for Staten Island's first tournament next October, and it was the first time she had played any kind of bridge without an experienced adviser at her elbow. She is only 9 years old.

abstract: A few months ago it appeared that the quid pro quo for airline deregulation legislation would be Federal money to help the airlines meet new aircraft noise standards. Only by supporting noise control subsidies could the Administration muster the votes in the House to open air routes to new competitors and allow carriers to set their own fares. Congressional ardor for noise control funds has, however, cooled somewhat with ITports of fat airline profits, and the deregulation effort is now apparently strong enough to stand on its own.

abstract: Selected Letters of John O'Hara revd by Christopher Lehmann-Haupt; O'Hara por
snippet: Selected Letters of John O'Hara revd by Christopher Lehmann-Haupt; O'Hara por
lead_paragraph: IT is now more than eight years since John O'Hara died, and though it is still not outlandish to surmise that he may one day be the writer people read to learn what life in America was like during the first half of the 20th century, his own prediction of an O'Hara boom has not yet come to pass, at least so far as I'm aware. (“I think I know my place in Am. Lit. as of five or 10 years after cool, but I would love to enjoy some of now, while I am alive,” he wrote to friend in 1960.)

abstract: ed holds progress has been made in Middle East peace talks since Sadat's visit to Jerusalem; calls on Pres Carter to make specific suggestions for settlement during forthcoming Camp David meeting (M)
snippet: ed holds progress has been made in Middle East peace talks since Sadat's visit to Jerusalem; calls on Pres Carter to make specific suggestions for settlement during forthcoming Camp David meeting (M)
lead_paragraph: When in trouble, call in the President. That is the significance of next month's Middle East summit at Camp David. Anwar Sadat's public disappointment with the rigidities of Israeli diplomacy have made it politically impossible for him to meet Menachem Begin again without the leavening presence of Jimmy Carter. It is very much to the President's credit that he is willing so directly to tie his own prestige to the continuation of the peacemaking process.

Shenefield, chief of the Justice Department's antitrust division, said there was a serious possibility that public restraints through regulation would pose longrun threats to competition and consumer interests. abstract: performance of Southside Johnny and the Asbury Jukes as part of festival revd by Robert Palmer; Johnny illus (S)
snippet: performance of Southside Johnny and the Asbury Jukes as part of festival revd by Robert Palmer; Johnny illus (S)
lead_paragraph: DEVELOPING a rock style usually has more to do with effecting a synthesis than with ‘,creating a language. Even the earliest rock‐and‐roll was a synthesis of country and blues, and although the music has not lacked creative figures who effected bold, original changes, for the most part it has progressed a step at a time, building on wbet came before. Sometimes, especial& in, periods like this one; when innovation is at a premium, an artist will forge a style out of ‘elements that have been neglected for a while, elements that belong to earlier strata of the rock tradition. If the elements are combined seamlessly enough and with enough personality and flair, the resulting style will ‘be just as new and just as valid as styles created out of more contemporary components.

abstract: DOES heavy trading volume increase or reduce the price stability of a stock? Conventional wisdom holds that on days that a stock trades heavily, its price pattern is likely to be less stable. nowever, it can De argued that as volume passes some critical level, the auction market gives way specialized institutional trading techniques, such as “crosses,” in which one broker acts for both buyer and seller. It may be that such techniques act to improve price stability under such circumstances.

abstract: Red Smith comment on career of Hall of Fame pitcher Jesse Joseph (Pop) Haines, following his death at 85 (L)
snippet: Red Smith comment on career of Hall of Fame pitcher Jesse Joseph (Pop) Haines, following his death at 85 (L)
lead_paragraph: On the same weekend when Eddie Mathews, a batter, was inducted into the Hall of Fame, Jesse Joseph Haines, pitcher already enshrined for the ages, took off for the big bull pen in the sky. Pop Haines was 85 years old and lust wore out, though that was uncharacteristii. Not counting the 1918 season, when he had a cup of coffee with the Cincinnati Reds. Pop played 18 years in a row for the St. Louis Cardinals, breaking, in at the age of 26 and continuing to ornament the Major league scene until he was going on 45. As late as his 42d year he was a World Series pitcher, and when at last the Cardinals turned him loose, it wasn't because he had nothing left. They released him so he could try his hand at managing in the minors. That turned out to be not, his dish. He had hated the constant. travel and the hotel living in the majors and he couldn't abide the bus hauls and fleabags of the bushes.
headline: {'main': 'Pop Haines and Other Deities', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Pop Haines and Other Deities', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: It is reasonable to assume that beer, one of the earliest of man's fermented beverages, was one of humanity's earliest cooking liquids. In the kitchen, flat as old seltzer or effervescent as new champagne, it has an impressive spectrum of uses. Below are three of them — a bread, the best carbonnade flamande we've ever eaten, from Isabelle Marique, proprietor of the Marique School of French Cooking in Manhattan, and a beer soup. Reactions to such a soup vary. To some it is a curious delight. Others find it vile and not without reason.

abstract: EVERY eater, no matter how dedicated, intrepid or sophisticated, now and then feels the need gain comfort from one of perhaps several security‐blanket foods, soothing and satisfying palliatives to frazzled nerves and frayed tempers, or overstimulated psyches and palates in need of gentle surcease. abstract: JUST when you thought it was safe to listen someone jaw, we have this memorial to conversation in the summer of ‘78: “While sitting around a swimming pool at Westhampton Beach last week,” writes Molly Towbin, “I observed a beautiful towheaded boy, about 21/2 years old, with his parents. abstract: Ways to break the Mideast deadlock will be discussed by President Carter, President Anwar el‐Sadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel on Sept. 5 at Camp David, Md., the White House announced. A senior Administration official said that Mr. Carter had decided to arrange the summit meeting “not because the chances for peace are right now so high, but because the stakes in peace are very high” and “the risks, in fact, have risen.” [Page Al, Columns 5.6.]

abstract: COOKING is an adventure and one of the most intriguing aspects of it can innovations that come about by blending foods on an international scale. One of the best and most hastily made Greek dishes is known as “garides me feta” —shrimp baked with feta cheese. There are many variations the dish; dill is sometimes added, or parsley, or capers. snippet: Elmont Memorial hs athlete Peter Arena, 17, dies after brief exercise; autopsy fails to disclose cause of death (S)
lead_paragraph: A star athlete at the Elmont Memorial High School in Elmont, L.I., collapsed and died at his home Monday night after tossing a football back and forth with friend for about an hour. The youth, Peter Arena, 17 years old, who was to have entered his senior year at the high school this fall, returned to his home at 2081 Baylis Avenue, and collapsed. An autopsy failed to disclose the cause of death.

abstract: THIS was before the air‐conditioner dropped out of the ninth‐floor window of a nearby apartment house, bounced off the roof of the seedy disco and ricocheted into my garden. It was before my newspaper took away all our typewriters, took away all our noise, and gave us machines with ghosts in them, machines that watch us while we try to write. It was before Billy Martin and Peter Bourne and Christina Onassis and the test‐tube baby and the inscrutable yen. It was, in other words, back in the days, just a few weeks ago, when thought I could cope.

abstract: Frank J Prial discusses domestic and imported beers (M)
snippet: Frank J Prial discusses domestic and imported beers (M)
lead_paragraph: The writer Joseph Wechsberg once recalled how, as young man, he traveled the world selling brewery supplies to lonely German and Czech brewmasters who had migrated to China, Java, Japan and Milwaukee to ply their trade. In fact, most good beers in the world still show the strong influence of those old Middle Europeans. Everywhere, that is, but in this country. Somehow, we have managed to produce an almost characterless product that bears only a vague resemblance to the rich, full‐bodied, full‐flavored beers produced abroad.

abstract: So vhat, you may well say. So what if there's yet another little bag that miraculously unzips and ends up as a more than generous big bag. So this is to tell you that there is now a bag that not only converts from small to big, but is as handsome can be. The bag has a couple of other features that are worthy of note. It changes size so simply that even people who are all thumbs (I confess) are able to handle and the price is moderate by almoSt any standard. There.are three sizeg, with the smallest version selling for about $14, the middle one for $22, or thereabout, and larlest for around $35. Each starts out as a neat‐looking, long‐shoulder‐strap compact. and expands to a carrying case with double handles. There's ample room side for a casual weekend wardrobe, and there are also two outside pockets, one with flap and one with zipper. The colors include brown, dark green and black, with a camel trim, and the design comes from a company called Pavanne. The luggage department at Saks Fifth Avenue, and the Plymouth stores are among those who have ordered the bag and, all things being equal, should have it by now.

abstract: BAGUIO, the Philippines, Aug (Reuters) — Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union and Viktor Korchnoi tonight battled to their ninth draw in the World Chess Championship after their fragile personal relations had sunk to the lowest level so far.
lead_paragraph: BAGUIO, the Philippines, Aug (Reuters) — Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union and Viktor Korchnoi tonight battled to their ninth draw in the World Chess Championship after their fragile personal relations had sunk to the lowest level so far. in a game in which neither player shone, Karpov made the mistake of trying to rush his opponent while Korchnoi was having his characteristic time trouble. Karpov, the present champion, landed himself in a tangle and threw away his advantage.

lead_paragraph: HE leader of the American Civil Liberties Union's successful support of the right of American Nazis to march in Skokie, Ill., is resigning from his post. David M. Hamlin, executive director of the A.C.L.U.'s Illinois division. said. “I wish to make abundantly clear that my resignation is no way a repudiation of the work I have done or the prganization I have served.” Fatigue was one factor in his decision, said Mr. Hamlin, who was in his post for four years. He said would like to do some writing, possibly about the civil liberties group's successful Supreme Court challenges of a series of Skokie ordinances designed to prevent the Nazis’ march.

abstract: Ways to break the Mideast deadlock will be discussed by President Carter, President Anwar el‐Sadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel on Sept. 5 at Camp David, Md., the White House announced. A senior Administration official said that Mr. Carter had decided to arrange the summit meeting “not because the chances for peace are right now so high, but because the stakes in peace are very high” and “the risks, in fact, have risen.” [Page Al, Columns 5‐5.]

lead_paragraph: THE Forest Hills tennis stadium is a fine place for popular music, with a concert capacity of 12,500 combined with a nice sense of intimacy. But with threatenine ram ciouas, lightning and humidly heavy air—not to speak of jets roaring overhead — it can't be said that circumstances were ideal Monday night for Linda Ronstadt's only New York concert of the year. At least, she and her audience could be grateful that she was able to get through the concert without anyone's getting wet; it had been scheduled for Sunday and was rained out.

lead_paragraph: The President's proposed reform of Civil Service is due to reach the House this week, and members will have an opportunity to undo the mischief done by their Civil Service Committee. By giving thousands of Federal unions the right to bargain over Governmentwide regulations, the amended measure threatens to bring chaos into personnel management. By putting strict limits on the duration and extent of the ‘President's proposed senior executive service, it would discourage career officials from taking part in a plan designed to cultivate talent. And in adding provisions to reform the Hatch Act, which restricts political action by Federal employees, it has invited defeat in the Senate, which has already approved most of the President's package but which opposes any such change.
